11\n|colspan=\"100\" align=\"center\" bgcolor=\"FAF6F6\"|[[Total Eclipse of the Heart]]\n|colspan=\"100\" align=\"center\" bgcolor=\"FAF6F6\"|[[Bonnie Tyler]]\n|colspan=\"100\" align=\"center\" bgcolor=\"FAF6F6\"|Safe\n|-\n|-\n|colspan=\"100\" align=\"center\" bgcolor=\"FAF6F6\"|Top 10\n|colspan=\"100\" align=\"center\" bgcolor=\"FAF6F6\"|[[On the Side of Angels]]\n|colspan=\"100\" align=\"center\" bgcolor=\"FAF6F6\"|[[LeAnn Rimes]]\n|colspan=\"100\" align=\"center\" bgcolor=\"FAF6F6\"|Eliminated\n|}{{Clear}}\n\n==Post ''Idol''==\nAfter ''[[American Idol]]'', Jessica Sierra performed all over the world. She sang at many concerts and private events, including a private event in [[Kazakhstan]]. Jessica did concerts for charities such as the [[Special Olympics]], and performed at numerous corporate events including shows sponsored by [[Kelloggs]] and [[Edy's|Edy's Ice Cream]]. In July 2006 Jessica visited U.S. soldiers in [[Iraq]] and [[Kuwait]], performing six shows for an [[Independence Day (United States)|Independence Day]] celebration including a July 4 show in [[Baghdad]].\n\nIn 2006, Jessica was featured in ''[[OK! Magazine]]'' and appeared on [[TV Guide Channel]]'s program ''Idol Tonight''.\n\n===2006\u20132008: First record deal, \"Unbroken\" and Celebrity Rehab ===\nIn late 2006, Jessica recorded a song, \"Unbroken\", for a [[Toys \"R\" Us]] Exclusive CD that came with the purchase of a [[Sony]] CD player. It was released as a single in early 2007 on [[iTunes]].\n\nOn January 8, 2008, Verge Management released Sierra's ''Deepest Secret'' EP on [[iTunes]], [[Amazon.com]],  and [[Rhapsody (online music service)|Rhapsody]]. On March 14, 2008, Sierra's ''[[Deepest Secret]]'' EP was made available in CD format via her official website: http://www.jessicasierra.com/. On March 15, 2008, Jessica's video for her single \"Unbroken\" was released. \"Unbroken\" is the song that Jessica sang on VH1 ''[[Celebrity Rehab with Dr. Drew]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2gaZbwHym7k|title=Jessica Sierra \"Unbroken\" Music Video|date=14 March 2008 |via=www.youtube.com}}</ref>\n\nSierra exited Verge records shortly after Celebrity Rehab, and signed with a new record label for her upcoming debut album. \"Unbroken\" was the only single released with Verge.\n\nSierra has since been clean and sober for 18 months, and thanks Dr. Drew Pinsky for saving her life.\n\n===2010\u20132012: new label, release of ''Rebound''===\nIn 2010, Sierra signed with a new record label called Elite B Records and released her new single \"Enough\" and released the music video online in October 2010, but it did not chart. Her debut album ''Rebound'' was due to be released in December 2010. In January 2011, after her album was not released she stated that it had been pushed back for a 2011 release to finish some songs. The album was never released.\n\n==Personal life==\nAs of 2011, Sierra was a resident of [[Vacaville, California]].<ref>\"Season 1 Revisited.\"  ''Celebrity Rehab with Dr. Drew''.  Hst. Dr. Drew Pinsky.  VH1.  20 Nov. 2011.</ref> She is a mother of two sons named Kayden Cash<ref>[http://celebritybabies.people.com/2009/12/09/american-idols-jessica-sierra-welcomes-son-kayden-cash/ American Idol's Jessica Sierra Welcomes Son Kayden Cash]</ref> and Sebastian Evans.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mjsbigblog.com/jessica-sierra-has-second-son-sebastian-evans.htm|title=Jessica Sierra Has Second Son Sebastian Evans|first=Mj|last=Santilli|date=March 4, 2011|website=mjsbigblog}}</ref>\n\n===Stalking incident===\nA 59-year-old man from California was arrested on January 17, 2006 at the home of Sierra's grandmother. Tampa police reported that Daniel Young left at least 40 voice mail messages telling Sierra that he loved her and was willing to go to jail for her.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment|title=Entertainment|website=ABC News}}</ref> Sierra was a spokesperson for the [[United States Department of Justice]]'s National Stalking Resource Center, and was featured in a national campaign to promote awareness of the risks of and remedies for [[stalking]]; Diane Stuart, Director of the Office on Violence Against Women, United States Department of Justice, worked with Sierra on this project.\n\nThe incident was recalled by Sierra on [[Investigation Discovery|Investigation Discovery's]] ''Stalked: Someone's Watching.''<ref>{{Citation |last1=Mass |first1=Ethan |title=Idol Worship |date=2013-01-02 |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2454562/ |series=Stalked: Someone's Watching |access-date=2022-06-01 |last2=Riga |first2=Tony |last3=Strawn |first3=Kenny}}</ref>\n\n===Substance abuse and legal issues===\nOn April 29, 2007, Sierra was arrested at a Tampa bar after throwing a glass at a fellow bar patron. During her booking, cocaine was found in her purse; she subsequently was charged with assault and possession of cocaine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hcso.tampa.fl.us/pub/default.asp?%2FOnline%2Fqdisp%2Fbn%3D07027625|title=Charge report |access-date=June 2, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090906064445/http://www.hcso.tampa.fl.us/pub/default.asp?%2FOnline%2Fqdisp%2Fbn=07027625 |archive-date=September 6, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2007/11/20/Hillsborough/Ex__Idol__hopeful_avo.shtml|title=Hillsborough: Ex-'Idol' hopeful avoids prison}}</ref> Prior to her plea and sentencing on these charges, Sierra participated in a [[VH1]] [[Drug rehabilitation|rehab]] [[reality show]] run by Dr. [[Drew Pinsky]] of ''[[Loveline]]'' called ''[[Celebrity Rehab with Dr. Drew]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vh1.com/press/press_releases/2006_release/celebrehab_nov272007.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206072758/http://www.vh1.com/press/press_releases/2006_release/celebrehab_nov272007.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 6, 2007|title=VH1 Press &#124; Press Release<!-- Bot generated title -->}}</ref>  The television series, featuring Sierra and eight other celebrities, was filmed during the summer of 2007 and premiered on VH1 on January 10, 2008.\n\nOn November 19, 2007, after regular filming on Celebrity Rehab had ended but before the series aired, Sierra pleaded no contest in a [[Tampa]] courtroom to the [[assault]] and cocaine [[Drug possession|possession]] charges. and was sentenced to 12 months' [[probation]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2007/11/20/Hillsborough/Ex__Idol__hopeful_avo.shtml|title=Hillsborough: Ex-'Idol' hopeful avoids prison<!-- Bot generated title -->}}</ref> Less than 2 weeks later, on December 1, Sierra was arrested again at a Tampa bar, this time for disorderly intoxication (misdemeanor), resisting arrest without violence (misdemeanor), and violation of her probation. The police report of the incident stated that Sierra was out of control, offered a sexual favor to one of the arresting officers, and vomited in the police car.<ref>[http://www2.tbo.com/content/2007/dec/04/me-sierra-ranted-scrapped-offered-sex-report-says/ Sierra Ranted, Scrapped, Offered Sex, Report Says<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2007/12/04/Hillsborough/How_did_she_go_from__.shtml|title=Hillsborough: How did she go from 'Idol' to this?<!-- Bot generated title -->}}</ref><ref>[http://northeast2.tbo.com/content/2007/dec/12/ne-two-photographs-tell-the-story/ Two Photographs Tell The Story<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.today/20120711212001/http://northeast2.tbo.com/content/2007/dec/12/ne-two-photographs-tell-the-story/ |date=2012-07-11 }}</ref> On January 7, 2008, after spending 39 days in jail without benefit of bond, she was sentenced to time served plus 12 months in rehab at the Pasadena Recovery Center, the same California rehab center where Celebrity Rehab took place, and three additional years of probation. The judge's sentence followed a plea to the court on her behalf from Drew Pinsky, where he stated that while the treatment she received while on the show was not adequate considering her level of addiction, he felt that she would have a better chance of recovery if she participated in a year-long treatment program.<ref>[http://www2.tbo.com/content/2008/jan/08/me-sierra-put-in-rehab-a-year-3-years-probation-to/ Sierra Put In Rehab For Year; 3 Years' Probation To Follow<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> As part of her probation terms, instead of a possible ten-year prison stint, Sierra was also prevented from getting within 100 yards of a camera or microphone, a restriction that kept her from participating in the reunion episode of Celebrity Rehab 1 as well as in update interviews for American Idol Season 4's Rewind episodes.<ref>[http://www2.tbo.com/content/2008/jan/11/102312/me-judge-scolds-sierra-about-talking-to-media/ Judge Scolds Sierra About Talking To Media<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www2.tbo.com/content/2008/dec/28/280014/na-where-are-they-now1/ Follow Up On This Year's Faces In The News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>\n\nIn March 2009, Pinsky stated in interviews and on his Twitter account that he had recently presented Sierra with her one year of sobriety celebration cake and that she was \"a new woman\". He also noted on his VH1 blog that court-mandated treatment had saved her life.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.vh1.com/2009-03-12/examining-sober-house-with-dr-drew-finale/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090316214415/http://blog.vh1.com/2009-03-12/examining-sober-house-with-dr-drew-finale/|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 16, 2009|title=Examining Sober House With Dr. Drew \u2013 Finale &#124; Vh1 Blog<!-- Bot generated title -->}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.twitter.com/drdrew|title=Dr Drew (@drdrew) &#124; Twitter|website=www.twitter.com}}</ref>\n\nOn April 15, 2009, a Florida judge lifted the media ban restriction on Sierra. It was noted in court that she had tested clean and sober for about a year and a half.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.myfoxtampabay.com/dpp/news/local/hillsborough/jessica_sierra_tampa_041509 |title=Fallen 'Idol' wins round in court<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=2009-04-18 |archive-date=2012-02-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120214190119/http://www.myfoxtampabay.com/dpp/news/local/hillsborough/jessica_sierra_tampa_041509 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/courts/criminal/article992568.ece|title=Lights, camera, action: Judge lifts gag order on Jessica Sierra \u2013 St. Petersburg Times<!-- Bot generated title -->|access-date=2009-04-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090419155707/http://www.tampabay.com/news/courts/criminal/article992568.ece|archive-date=2009-04-19|url-status=dead}}</ref> On April 29, two years to the date after her initial 2007 arrest, Sierra credited Dr. Drew Pinsky with saving her life in a taped interview.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.eonline.com/|title=Entertainment News, Celebrity News, Celebrity Gossip &#124; E! News|website=E! Online}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/lat-sierra_kj2e9wnc20090601121834,0,13733.photo|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102144323/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/lat-sierra_kj2e9wnc20090601121834,0,13733.photo|url-status=dead|archive-date=2012-11-02|title=Jessica Sierra \u2013 latimes.com<!-- Bot generated title -->|website=[[Los Angeles Times]] }}</ref>\n\nThat same year, Sierra and other alumni of ''Celebrity Rehab'' appeared as panel speakers to a new group of addicts at the Pasadena Recovery Center, marking 18 months of sobriety for her.  Her appearance was aired in the third season episode \"Triggers\".<ref name=Triggers>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vh1.com/video/celebrity-rehab-3/full-episodes/triggers/1631736/playlist.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100215131451/http://www.vh1.com/video/celebrity-rehab-3/full-episodes/triggers/1631736/playlist.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=February 15, 2010|title=Celebrity Rehab with Dr. Drew Episode 3.6 (\"Triggers\") VH1|date=February 11, 2010}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n*2011: ''Rebound'' (shelved)\n\n===Singles===\n*2007: \"Unbroken\"\n*2010: \"Enough\"\n\n===EPs===\n*2008: ''[[Deepest Secret]]''\n\n===Music videos===\n*2007: \"Unbroken\"\n*2010: \"Enough\"\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{Official Website}}\n*[https://web.archive.org/web/20080107130846/http://www.vh1.com/shows/dyn/celebrity_rehab_with_dr_drew/series.jhtml?source=globalnav Celebrity Rehab]\n*[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2gaZbwHym7k Jessica's ''Unbroken'' Music Video]\n\n{{American Idol 4}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Sierra, Jessica}}\n[[Category:1985 births]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singers]]\n[[Category:American child singers]]\n[[Category:American Idol participants]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Tampa, Florida]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Casey_James","to":"Casey James"}],"pages":{"26250218":{"pageid":26250218,"ns":0,"title":"Casey James","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{Distinguish|Kasey James|James Casey (disambiguation)}}\n{{Use American English|date=January 2023}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2023}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Casey James\n| image           = Casey James.jpg\n| caption         = Casey James in July 2010\n| image_size      = 220px\n| birth_name      = Casey Everett James\n| birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|1982|5|31}}\n| birth_place     = [[Plano, Texas]]\n| origin          = [[Fort Worth, Texas]], {{nowrap|United States}}\n| instrument      = [[Singing|Vocal]]s, [[guitar]], [[mandolin]]\n| genre           = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[Country music|country]], [[Rock music|rock]], [[Blues music|blues]]<ref name=\"AI-contCJ\"/>\n| occupation      = Singer, songwriter\n| years_active    = 2008\u2013present\n| label           = [[BNA Records|BNA]] (2010-12)<br>[[19 Recordings|19]] (2010-2015)<br>[[Columbia Records|Columbia]] (2012-2015)\n| website         = [http://www.caseyjamesofficial.com www.caseyjamesoffical.com]\n}}\n\n'''Casey Everett James''' (born May 31, 1982)<ref name=\"AI-HB\">[http://www.americanidol.com/news/view/pid/3323/ \"Happy Birthday, Casey James and Michael Lynche\"]. AmericanIdol.com. FOX. June 1, 2010.</ref> is an American [[singing|singer]] and [[guitarist]] who was the third-place finalist on the [[American Idol (season 9)|ninth season]] of ''[[American Idol]]'' and is an independent recording artist.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1832433972/casey-james-independent-studio-album|title=Casey James: Independent Studio Album|website=Kickstarter|access-date=August 12, 2017}}</ref> He released his [[Casey James (album)|eponymous album]] in March 2012 from which three singles, \"[[Let's Don't Call It a Night]]\", \"[[Crying on a Suitcase]]\", and \"The Good Life\" were released. In October 2014, James released \"Fall Apart\" as the first single from a planned second studio album, but Sony opted not to release the record and they split ways. In 2017, James released his second album, ''Strip It Down'', to critical acclaim.\n\n==Early life==\nJames was born on May 31, 1982, in [[Plano, Texas]], to Debra \"Bybee\" and Beau James.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thecountrysite.com/2012/05/31/happy-29th-birthday-to-casey-jones-watch-a-very-special-tribute-video-to-casey-from-a-fan-named-ana/ |title=Happy 30th Birthday To Casey James \u2013 Watch A Very Special Tribute Video To Casey From A Fan Named Ana |work=The Country Site |date=May 31, 2011 |access-date=January 9, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140706010817/http://thecountrysite.com/2012/05/31/happy-29th-birthday-to-casey-jones-watch-a-very-special-tribute-video-to-casey-from-a-fan-named-ana/ |archive-date=July 6, 2014 |url-status=dead }}</ref> The family moved to [[Princeton, Texas]], but after his parents divorced when James was about four, his mother raised him and his brother Billy Cole in [[Cool, Texas]].<ref name=\"DebraBybee\">{{cite web|url=http://voices.yahoo.com/in-depth-interview-casey-james-mother-debra-bybee-6401020.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130217032417/http://voices.yahoo.com/in-depth-interview-casey-james-mother-debra-bybee-6401020.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 17, 2013 |title=In-Depth Interview with Casey James' Mother, Debra \"Bybee\" James -- Part One |author=Shari Geller |work=Yahoo! Voices |date=July 14, 2010 }}{{unreliable source?|date=October 2015}}</ref> James had a bad reaction to his [[pertussis]] (whooping cough) vaccine when he was an infant, and his family feared brain damage.<ref name=\"AI-contCJ\">[http://www.americanidol.com/contestants/season_9/casey_james/ \"Casey James - Season 9 Contestants -  American Idol\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100313074708/http://www.americanidol.com/contestants/season_9/casey_james/ |date=March 13, 2010 }}. AmericanIdol.com. FOX. Retrieved March 17, 2010.</ref><ref name=\"AI-RS\">{{Cite episode |title= Rolling Stones Episode |series=American Idol |series-link=American Idol (season 9) |network=Fox |airdate=March 16, 2010 |season=Nine}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/realitycheck/blog/2010/03/american_idol_top_12_perform_1.html | title='American Idol': Top 12 perform |last=Kelber |first=Sarah |newspaper=Baltimore Sun |date=March 16, 2010 |access-date=March 17, 2010}}</ref> According to his mother, however, she realized that he would be all right and was going to be musical when he started humming the theme song from [[M*A*S*H (TV series)|M*A*S*H]].<ref name=\"AI-RS\"/>\n\n[[File:Casey-James-AI Tour.jpg|thumb|right|James performing on the American Idol Live! tour in Denver, Colorado, on August 23, 2010]]\n\nJames started playing the guitar at 13 and within a year was playing on stage. James has played acoustic sets with his mother, and blues with his older brother.  He has also played with country and rock bands.<ref>Montgomery, James (May 19, 2010). [https://web.archive.org/web/20100520033630/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1639470/20100518/story.jhtml \"'American Idol' Finalist Casey James Was Always 'A Throwback' - News Story\"]. MTV Networks.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mineralwellsindex.com/homepage/x1414102308/You-can-go-home/print |title=You can go home |last=Cluett |first=Libby |date=May 15, 2010 |work=Mineral Wells Index, Mineral Wells, TX |publisher=Community Newspaper Holdings}}</ref> At the age of 21, he was in a serious motorcycle accident that nearly ended his life.  He was told by his doctor that he would no longer be able to play guitar, a medical prediction that proved untrue.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1633834/20100312/story.jhtml | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100316235242/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1633834/20100312/story.jhtml | url-status = dead | archive-date = March 16, 2010 |title=Casey James Profile: Can The Sex Symbol Become 'Idol' Champ? |last=Cantiello |first=Jim |publisher=MTV | date=March 12, 2010 |access-date=March 17, 2010}}</ref> During the ''American Idol'' hometown visits, James returned to the hospital where he was treated for his injuries and presented an autographed guitar to his surgeon, Dr. Cory Collinge.<ref>[http://tvwatch.people.com/2010/05/15/casey-james-idol-texas-homecoming/ \"Casey James's Sleepless (and Emotional) Texas-Sized Homecoming\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100719124102/http://tvwatch.people.com/2010/05/15/casey-james-idol-texas-homecoming/ |date=July 19, 2010 }}. May 15, 2010. PEOPLE TV Watch. Time Inc.</ref>\n\nBefore ''American Idol'', he played with his band, The Casey James Band, consisting of James, his brother, Billy Cole (bass), and Jacy McCann (drums). They recorded four songs, including the first song that James ever wrote, \"Freezing,\" back in 2002.\n\n==Musical influences==\nJames cites blues guitarist [[Doyle Bramhall II]] as a major musical influence and whom he would most like to perform with in his Idol Q&A.<ref name=\"AI-contCJ\"/> Another major influence is [[Stevie Ray Vaughan]]; James named Vaughan's ''[[In the Beginning (Stevie Ray Vaughan album)|In the Beginning]]'' (1992) as a formative album in his early years.\n\n<blockquote>I got an album called \u201cIn the Beginning\u201d and I learned every note on it, which was easier to do because it was early on in his career [it was recorded in 1980]. I learned all those notes and it opened me up to the blues. When you look what he was doing, a lot of it was covers, and then you go back and start listening to those guys -- the originals Albert King, Freddie King, Albert Collins -- those influences changed me, too.</blockquote>\n\nOther influences cited in the article are southern rockers [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]] and [[Pearl Jam]].<ref>[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/americanidoltracker/2010/05/casey-james-the-soundtrack-to-my-life.html \"Casey James: The soundtrack to my life.\"]. Idol Tracker. May 19, 2010. LA Times.</ref>\n\n==''American Idol''==\nJames was a contestant on ''[[American Idol]]'' during its ninth season. He made it to the Top 3 before being eliminated on May 19, 2010. James had tried out for and been selected to compete in the ninth season of ''Idol'' in 2009 in spite of the fact that he had never seen the show.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/idolchatter/post/2010/03/casey-james-turns-into-a-triple-threat-with-gavin-degraw-and-his-guitar/1 |title=Casey James turns into a triple threat with Gavin DeGraw and his guitar |work=USA Today: Idol Chatter |date=March 2, 2010 |access-date=March 17, 2010}}</ref> He was the oldest contestant to be selected for the Top 24 of the ninth season at the age of 27. James was voted off of the competition on May 19, 2010, and finished in third place. During the finale of ''American Idol'', he performed a duet of \"[[Every Rose Has Its Thorn]]\" with [[Bret Michaels]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100606165914/http://newsroom.mtv.com/2010/06/03/bret-michaels-casey-james/ \"Bret Michaels And Casey James Hit It Off Right Away: The MTV News Quote Of The Day\"]. June 3, 2010. MTV Newsroom. MTV Networks.</ref>\n\n''[[USA Today]]'' music critic [[Brian Mansfield]] suggested that James was \"the best guitar player the show [''American Idol''] has seen.\"<ref>{{cite news |title=Here's the scoop on the 'American Idol' Chosen 12 |last=Mansfield |first=Brian |date=March 12, 2010 |access-date=March 17, 2010 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2010-03-12-idolfinalists12_ST_N.htm |work=USA Today |quote=Casey James: Arguably the broadest musical background of the 12 and best guitar player the show has seen.}}</ref>\n\n=== Performances ===\n{|class=\"wikitable\" style=\"text-align: center;\"\n|-\n!Episode\n!Theme\n!Song choice\n!Original artist\n!Order #\n!Result\n|-\n|Audition\n|N/A\n|\"[[Slow Dancing in a Burning Room]]\"\n|[[John Lennon]]\n|7\n|Safe\n|-\n|Top 9{{ref|1|1}}\n|[[Elvis Presley]]\n|\"[[Lawdy Miss Clawdy]]\"\n|[[Lloyd Price]]\n|9\n|Safe\n|-\n|Top 7\n|Inspirational\n|\"[[Don't Stop (Fleetwood Mac song)|Don't song)|Blue Skies]]\"\n|[[Belle Baker]]\n|2\n|Safe\n|-\n|rowspan=\"2\"| Top 4\n|rowspan=\"2\"| Songs of the Cinema\n| <small>[[Solo (music)|Solo]] </small> \"[[Mrs. Robinson]]\" \u2014 ''[[The Graduate]]''\n| [[Simon & Garfunkel]]\n| 4\n|rowspan=\"2\"| Safe\n|-\n| <small>[[Duet (music)|Duet]] </small> \"[[Have You Ever Really Loved a Woman?]]\" \u2014 ''[[Don Juan DeMarco]]'' with [[Michael Lynche]]\n|Bryan Adams\n|6\n|-\n|rowspan=\"2\"| Top 3\n| Contestant's Choice\n| \"[[Sounds Like This|OK, It's Alright with Me]]\"\n| [[Eric Hutchinson]]\n| 1\n|rowspan=\"2\"| Eliminated\n|-\n|Judge's Choice{{ref|4|4}}\n|\"[[Daughters (John Mayer song)|Daughters]]\"\n|John Mayer\n|4\n|}\n*<small>{{note|1|Note 1}} Due to the judges using their one save to save [[Michael Lynche]], the Top 9 remained intact for another week.</small>\n*<small>{{note|2|Note 2}} When [[Ryan Seacrest]] announced the results for this particular night, James was among the Bottom 3 but declared safe second, as [[Tim Urban]] was eliminated.</small>\n*<small>{{note|3|Note 3}} When Ryan Seacrest announced the results for this particular night, James was among the Bottom 3 but declared safe second, as [[Siobhan Magnus]] was eliminated.</small>\n*<small>{{note|4|Note 4}} Song selected by [[Randy Jackson]] and [[Kara DioGuardi]].</small>\n\n==Post-''Idol''==\nJames joined the rest of the Top 10 on the [[American Idols LIVE! Tour 2010|American Idols LIVE!]] tour. His four-song set included \"I Got Mine\" by The Black Keys, \"Don't\" by Shania Twain, \"It's All Over Now\" by Bobby Womack, and \"Have You Ever Really Loved a Woman\" by Bryan Adams alongside fellow contestant [[Michael Lynche]].\n\nIn March 2011 he opened for Sugarland on their The Incredible Machine Tour<ref>{{cite web|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/idolchatter/post/2011/01/casey-james-to-open-for-sugarland/1 |title=Casey James to open for Sugarland |last=Mansfield |first=Brian |work=Idol Chatter |publisher=USA Today, a division of Gannett |date=January 27, 2011}}</ref> and has been playing other solo and opening gigs including performing at the ACM Awards fan party<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acmcountry.com/events/fanjam.php |title=Rihanna to Join Country Acts Partying with Sugarland at ACM Fan Jam |work=acmcountry.com |publisher=Academy of Country Music |access-date=September 27, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927050235/http://www.acmcountry.com/events/fanjam.php |archive-date=September 27, 2011 }}</ref> and 2011 CMA Fest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lineup.cmaworld.com/band/casey-james |title=Casey James at CMA Music Fest 2011 |work=lineup.cmaworld.com |publisher=Country Music Association |access-date=September 27, 2011}}</ref>\n\n===2012: ''Casey James''===\nOn August 17, 2010, it was announced that James had signed with [[Sony Music Nashville]] and his debut album would be released on [[BNA Records]]/[[19 Recordings|19]] in 2011.<ref>[http://content.usatoday.com/communities/idolchatter/post/2010/08/its-official-casey-james-signs-with-sony-music-nashville/1 \"It's official: Casey James signs with Sony Music Nashville\"]. August 17, 2010. USA Today.</ref> Sony Music Nashville Chairman and CEO Gary Overton said: \"We at Sony Music Nashville are incredibly excited about signing CASEY JAMES. I flew to NEW YORK to see him 'live' with the American Idol Tour and I was blown away with his voice, guitar playing and stage presence...and so were the thousands of fans in the amphitheatre. He has honed his skills as a showman with his years of performing live on stage! I can't wait to get him into the studio to begin recording his debut album.\"<ref>[http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/79465/casey-james-signs-with-19-recordings-bna-records \"Casey James Signs With 19 Recordings/BNA Records\"]. August 17, 2010. AllAccess.com.</ref> James worked with country songwriter [[Tom Douglas (songwriter)|Tom Douglas]]. Douglas has said of James that \"he's the real deal. He's a great singer and great guitar player, so I'm looking forward to writing with him.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/473407/reznor-rahman-zimmer-more-react-to-their-oscar-nominations |title=Reznor, Rahman, Zimmer & More React to Their Oscar Nominations |date=January 25, 2011 |last1=Herrera |first1=Monica |last2=Lipshutz |first2=Jason |last3=Mapes |first3=Jillian |work=Billboard.com |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]}}</ref>  James collaborated with some of country music's notable songwriters including [[Aimee Mayo]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ascap.com/ace/search.cfm?requesttimeout=300&mode=results&searchstr=882985428&search_in=i&search_type=exact&search_det=t,s,w,p,b,v&results_pp=10&start=1 |title=ACE Title Search |work=ascap.com |publisher=[[ASCAP]] |access-date=September 27, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]]'s [[Randy Owen]], Sugarland's [[Kristian Bush]], and [[Delbert McClinton]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mineralwellsindex.com/homepage/x108199938/Casey-James-playing-his-way-back-home |title=Casey James playing his way back home |last=Cluett |first=Libby |date=May 25, 2011 |work=Mineral Wells Index, Mineral Wells, TX |publisher=Community Newspaper Holdings}}</ref>\n\nJames first single, \"Let's Don't Call It a Night\", was released on August 15, 2011, and sold 5,000 copies in its debut week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/idolchatter/post/2011/08/country-singles-lead-idol-track-sales/1 |title=Country singles lead 'Idol' track sales |last=Mansfield |first=Brian |work=Idol Chatter |publisher=USA Today, a division of Gannett |date=August 24, 2011}}</ref>  James co-wrote \"Let's Don't Call It a Night\" with [[Brice Long]] and [[Terry McBride (musician)|Terry McBride]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bnarecords.com/artists/casey-james |title=Casey James &#124; BNA Records |access-date=February 3, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311192702/http://www.bnarecords.com/artists/casey-james |archive-date=March 11, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> James' self-titled debut CD was released on March 20, 2012, on BNA Records. James co-wrote nine of the CD's eleven tracks and co-produced the CD with [[Chris Lindsey]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/idolchatter/post/2012/01/casey-james-track-list-revealed/1 |title=Casey James track list revealed |last=Mansfield |first=Brian |work=Idol Chatter |publisher=USA Today|date=January 20, 2012}}</ref>\n\nOn June 4, 2012, James was moved to [[Sony Music Nashville|Columbia Nashville]], another division of Sony Music Nashville, after the closure of BNA Records.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/106752/kenny-chesney-renews-deal-with-sony-bna-imprint-re|title=Kenny Chesney Renews Deal With Sony, BNA Imprint Retired|date=June 4, 2012}}</ref> Shortly after, his second single \"Crying on a Suitcase\" was released on June 18, with a music video released in August.\n\n===2014-present===\nIn October 2014, James released \"Fall Apart\" as the first single from a second studio album.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/casey-james-new-single-fall-apart-20141006 |title=Hear Casey James' Heartbreaking New Single 'Fall Apart' |author=Stephen L. Betts |date=October 6, 2014 |magazine=Rolling Stone}}</ref>  However, Sony decided not to release this album and James and Sony separated. As an independent artist, James launched a Kickstarter in October 2016 to raise at least $30,000 for his new album,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://radiotvtalk.blog.ajc.com/2016/10/21/life-after-american-idol-adam-lambert-carrie-underwood-casey-james-clay-aiken/ |title=Life after 'American Idol': Adam Lambert, Carrie Underwood, Casey James, Clay Aiken |author=Rodney Ho|date=October 21, 2016 |work=AJC.com }}</ref> and surpassed this goal.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1832433972/casey-james-independent-studio-album/description |title=Casey James: Independent Studio Album |work=Kickstarter }}</ref> The album, ''Strip It Down'', received rave reviews. Rainey Wetnight of ''Blues Blast Magazine'' called the album \"outstanding\" and highlighted the track \"Bulletproof\", which features [[Delbert McClinton]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bluesblastmagazine.com/casey-james-strip-it-down-album-review/|author=Rainey Wetnight|title=Casey James \u2013 Strip It Down <nowiki>|</nowiki> Album Review|work=Blust Blast Magazine|date=November 29, 2017|access-date=January 22, 2019}}</ref> Alexandra Veltri of Bluesrockreview.com gave the album eight stars out of ten. She praised James for his vocals and guitar playing, while writing, \"Every note and lyric is in service to the song, the album, and the listener.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bluesrockreview.com/2017/11/casey-james-strip-it-down-review.html|author=Alexandra Veltri|title=Casey James: Strip It Down Review|work=Bluesrockreview.com|date=November 29, 2017|access-date=January 22, 2019}}</ref> Mark Franklin of the ''[[York Dispatch]]'' considered ''Strip It Down'' to be a more authentic representation of James as an artist than his previous album,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://idolchatteryd.com/top-5-post-american-idol-albums-of-2017/|author=Mark Franklin|title=Top 5 Post-American Idol Albums of 2017|work=Idol Chatter|publisher=[[York Dispatch]]|date=January 17, 2018|access-date=January 22, 2019}}</ref> calling it \"bluesier [and] much more rocking\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://idolchatteryd.com/casey-james-cuts-loose-on-new-bluesier-album/|author=Mark Franklin|title=Casey James Cuts Loose On New, Bluesier Album|work=Idol Chatter|publisher=York Dispatch|date=June 13, 2017|access-date=January 22, 2019}}</ref> As of 2022, James is a member of the group Texas Hill, along with [[Craig Wayne Boyd]] and Adam Wakefield.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.texashillofficial.com/about|title=Texas Hill Biography|access-date=July 9, 2022}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nJames had been convicted of three traffic violations and jailed prior to appearing on ''American Idol''.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://radaronline.com/exclusives/2010/02/exclusive-american-idol-hopeful-casey-james-jailbird-past/ |title=EXCLUSIVE: American Idol Hopeful Casey James' Jailbird Past |work=Radar Online |date=February 5, 2010 }}</ref>  He was also involved in serious motorcycle accident in 2004 that left him with a broken left arm and wrist, and a right femur with multiple compound fracture, and he was in a wheelchair for six months.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thehollywoodgossip.com/2010/03/ex-wife-of-casey-james-music-is-singers-life/ |title=Ex-Wife of Casey James: Music is Singer's Life  |work= The Hollywood Gossip |date= March 9, 2010 }}</ref>\n\nIn 2005, James married Kellie Marie whom he met when he was nineteen at Leaning Tree Church in Mineral Wells, Texas.<ref name=\"nashvillegab.com\">{{cite web|url=http://nashvillegab.com/2014/12/surprise-casey-james-is-a-married-man.html|title=Surprise! Casey James is a married man \u2013 NashvilleGab|website=nashvillegab.com|date=December 19, 2014 |access-date=August 12, 2017}}</ref><ref name=\"bio\">{{cite web|url=http://voices.yahoo.com/unofficial-biography-casey-james-6847594.html?cat=2 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130217035038/http://voices.yahoo.com/unofficial-biography-casey-james-6847594.html?cat=2 |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 17, 2013 |author=Shari Geller |title=September 24, 2010 }}{{unreliable source?|date=October 2015}}</ref> The marriage however did not last and they divorced two years later. In August 2014, Casey married Kelli Pentzer and in February 2016 they had a daughter, in December 2017 they had a son and in October 2019 they had another daughter.<ref name=\"nashvillegab.com\"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/casey-james-daughter-jocelyn/ |title=Baby Makes Five for Casey James and His Wife Kelli Sounds Like Nashville |website=Soundslikenashville.com |date=October 16, 2019 |access-date=March 15, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/casey-james-second-child/ |title=Casey James and Wife Welcome Second Child Sounds Like Nashville |website=Soundslikenashville.com |date=December 16, 2017 |access-date=March 15, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/casey-james-baby-girl/|title=Casey James Shows Off New Daughter with Adorable Photo|website=Taste of Country|date=February 16, 2016 |access-date=August 12, 2017}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n!
