This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Norah_Jones","to":"Norah Jones"}],"pages":{"184860":{"pageid":184860,"ns":0,"title":"Norah Jones","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American musician (born 1979)}}\n{{use mdy dates|date=October 2020}}\n{{Infobox person\n| name               = Norah Jones\n| image              = Norah Jones sings during Congressional Gold Medal Ceremony (cropped).jpg\n| caption            = Norah Jones at the [[U.S. Capitol]] in 2011\n| birth_name         = Geethali Norah Jones Shankar<!--Do not change birth name to new name; she changed it-->\n| birth_date         = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1979|3|30}}\n| birth_place        = [[New York City]], U.S.\n| origin             = \n| occupation         = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter|musician}}\n| father             = [[Ravi Shankar]]\n| mother             = [[Sue_Jones_(Ravi_Shankar)|Sue Jones]]\n| spouse             = Pete Remm\n| children           = 2\n| relatives          = {{plainlist}}\n* [[Anoushka Shankar]] (half-sister)\n* [[Shubhendra Shankar]] (half-brother)\n* [[Uday Shankar]] (uncle)\n* [[Amala Shankar]] (aunt)\n* [[Mamata Shankar]] (first cousin)\n* [[Viji Subramaniam]] (first cousin)\n* [[Gingger Shankar]] (first cousin once removed)\n{{endplainlist}}\n| module             = {{Infobox musical artist|embed=yes\n | background        = person\n | instrument        = {{hlist|Vocals|piano}}<!--Only for instrument(s) artist is primarily notable for using, per [[Template:Infobox_musical_artist/doc#instrument]]; \"The instruments infobox parameter is not intended as a WP:COATRACK for every instrument the subject has ever used\"-->\n | genre             = {{hlist|[[Pop music|Pop]]|[[jazz]]|[[folk music|folk]]|[[country music|country]]|[[blues]]<!--Aim for generality and use two to four genres: [[Template:Infobox_musical_artist/doc#genre]]--><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/norah-jones-mn0000884686/biography|title=Biography|work=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=June 4, 2018}}</ref>}}\n | years_active      = 2001\u2013present\n | label             = [[Blue Note Records|Blue Note]]\n | current_member_of = {{hlist|[[The Little Willies]]|[[Puss n Boots]]|[[El Madmo (album)|El Madmo]]}}\n | past_member_of = [[Wax Poetic]]\n }}\n}}\n'''Norah Jones''' ({{IPAc-en|\u02c8|n|\u0254\u02d0r|\u0259}} {{respell|NOR|\u0259}}; born '''Geethali Norah Jones Shankar'''; March 30, 1979)<ref name=\"ABC\">{{cite news |last=Dilworth |first=Thomas J. |title=What's Next for Norah Jones? |work=[[ABC News (United States)|ABC News]] |date=July 6, 2007 |url=https://abcnews.go.com/GMA/SummerConcert/story?id=3342169 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628203330/https://abcnews.go.com/GMA/SummerConcert/story?id=3342169 |url-status=dead |archive-date=June 28, 2011 |access-date=November 19, 2009 |quote= Hailing from Brooklyn, N.Y., is Norah Geethali Shankar, born on March 30, 1979. Shankar officially changed her name to Norah Jones when she was 16, and has been using it ever since.}}</ref> is an American singer-songwriter and pianist. She has won several awards for her music and, as of 2023, had sold more than 50 million records worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bluenote.com/artist/norah-jones/|title=Biography - Norah Jones|website=Bluenote.com|access-date=February 6, 2023|language=en}}</ref> ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' named her the top [[jazz]] artist of the 2000s decade. She has won nine [[Grammy Awards]] and was ranked 60th on ''Billboard'' magazine's artists of the 2000s decade chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/#/charts-decade-end/artists-of-the-decade?year=2009&begin=51&order=position |title=Artists of the Decade |magazine=Billboard.com |access-date=January 6, 2013}}</ref>\n\nIn 2002, Jones launched her solo music career with the release of ''[[Come Away with Me]]'', which was a fusion of jazz with [[Country music|country]], [[blues]], [[Folk music|folk]] and [[Pop music|pop]]. It was certified [[RIAA Certification#List of certifications|diamond]], selling over 27 million copies.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/fame-happened-too-fast-norah-jones-on-life-after-come-away-with-me-20160926-grou3d.html|title='Fame happened too fast': Norah Jones on life after Come Away With Me|first=Neil|last=McCormick|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=October 2, 2016|access-date=May 29, 2017}}</ref> The record earned Jones five [[Grammy Awards]], including the [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]], [[Grammy Award for Record of the Year|Record of the Year]], and [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]], making her the first person of [[South Asian]] descent to win that many Grammy awards.<ref name=\"CNN\">{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2003/SHOWBIZ/Music/02/28/mroom.norah.jones/ |title=Norah Jones sweeps Grammy Awards |publisher=CNN.com |date=February 28, 2003 |access-date=August 19, 2010}}</ref> Her subsequent studio albums ''[[Feels Like Home (Norah Jones album)|Feels Like Home]]'' (2004), ''[[Not Too Late (album)|Not Too Late]]'' (2007), and ''[[The Fall (Norah Jones album)|The Fall]]'' (2009), all gained [[RIAA Certification|platinum]] status, selling over a million copies each.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=tblDiamond |title=Gold & Platinum \u2013 August 19, 2010 |publisher=RIAA |access-date=August 19, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725044833/http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=tblDiamond |archive-date=July 25, 2013}}</ref> They were also generally well received by critics.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/person/norah-jones |title=Norah Jones Profile |work=Metacritic|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|access-date=July 6, 2016}}</ref> \nJones made her feature film debut as an actress in ''[[My Blueberry Nights]]'', which was released in 2007 and was directed by [[Wong Kar-Wai]].\n\nJones is the daughter of Indian [[sitar]]ist and composer [[Ravi Shankar]], and is the half-sister of fellow Indian musicians [[Anoushka Shankar]] and [[Shubhendra Shankar]].\n\n==Early life==\nJones was born Geethali Norah Jones Shankar on March 30, 1979, in [[Manhattan]], New York City, to American concert producer Sue Jones and Indian Bengali musician [[Ravi Shankar]].<ref name=\"ABC\"/><ref>{{cite news |last1=Choudhury |first1=Uttara |title=Norah Jones says her dad Ravi Shankar will be 'greatly missed' - Firstpost |work=www.firstpost.com |url=https://www.firstpost.com/living/norah-jones-says-her-dad-ravi-shankar-will-be-greatly-missed-555511.html |access-date=July 31, 2018}}</ref> \n\nAfter her parents separated in 1986, Jones lived with her mother, growing up in [[Grapevine, Texas]]. As a child, Jones began singing in church and also took piano and voice lessons. She and her mother lived in [[Anchorage, Alaska]] when she was eleven years old.<ref name=\"NPR 2016 u316\">{{cite web | title=< On Her Latest, Norah Jones Returns To Old Influences| website=NPR | date=15 October 2016 | url=https://www.npr.org/transcripts/496855218?storyId=496855218?storyId=496855218 | access-date=16 July 2024}}</ref> She attended Grapevine Middle School and [[Grapevine High School]] before transferring to [[Booker T. Washington High School for the Performing and Visual Arts]] in [[Dallas]]. Her music took its first form early on in the local Methodist Church where she regularly sang solos. While in high school, she sang in the school choir, participated in band, and played the alto saxophone. At the age of 16, with both parents' consent, she officially changed her name to Norah Jones.<ref name=\"ABC\" /><ref name=\"NPR 2013 u316\">{{cite web | title=Anoushka Shankar And Norah Jones: Half-Sisters Collaborate At Last | website=NPR | date=20 October 2013 | url=https://www.npr.org/2013/10/20/237107030/anoushka-shankar-and-norah-jones-half-sisters-collaborate-at-last | access-date=2 May 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Hard to say no to free love: Ravi Shankar |work=Press Trust of India |publisher=[[Rediff.com]] |date=April 29, 2003 |url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2003/may/13ravi.htm |access-date=June 20, 2014}}</ref>\n\nJones always had an affinity for the music of [[Bill Evans]] and [[Billie Holiday]], among other \"oldies\". She once said, \"My mom had this eight-album Billie Holiday set; I picked out one disc that I liked and played that over and over again\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yamaha.com/yasi/artists/details.html?CNTID=4102014&type=contemporary|work=Yamaha Artists Services, New York|title=Norah Jones|access-date=December 28, 2016}}</ref>\n\nShe attended [[Interlochen Center for the Arts]] during the summers. While at high school, she won the ''[[Down Beat]]'' Student Music Awards for Best Jazz Vocalist (twice, in 1996 and 1997) and Best Original Composition (1996).<ref>{{cite magazine |access-date=May 21, 2008 |url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=norah jones|bio=true}}|title=Norah Jones|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]}}</ref>\n\nJones attended the [[University of North Texas]] (UNT), where she majored in jazz piano and sang with the UNT Jazz Singers. During this time, she had a chance meeting with future collaborator [[Jesse Harris]]. She gave a ride to a band playing at the university whose members happened to be friends of Harris. He was on a cross-country [[road trip]] with friend and future [[The Little Willies|Little Willies]] member Richard Julian, and stopped to see the band play. After meeting Jones, Harris started sending her [[lead sheet]]s of his songs.\n\nIn 1999, Jones left Texas for New York City. Less than a year later, she started a band with Harris, and her recordings with them were bestsellers.<ref>{{cite serial |access-date=January 4, 2009 |url=http://128.163.130.14/woodsongs-318.wmv |title=Jesse Harris & Jennifer Daniels |series=WoodSongs Old Time Radio Hour|url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327131351/http://128.163.130.14/woodsongs-318.wmv |archive-date=March 27, 2009 }}</ref>\n\n==Musical career==\nJones was a [[lounge music|lounge singer]] before becoming a recording artist.<ref>{{cite web |access-date=May 21, 2008 |url=http://www.glidemagazine.com/index.php?task=Articles&section=94&id=46253&issue=1&PHPSESSID=53031 |title=Norah Jones 5/28/2003 |publisher=Glide Magazine |date=June 29, 2003 |author=Piccolo, Brian }}</ref> Before releasing her first studio album, she performed with [[Wax Poetic]], [[Peter Malick]], and jazz guitarist [[Charlie Hunter]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.charliehunter.com/discs/analogplayground.htm |title=CharlieHunter.com |publisher=CharlieHunter.com |access-date=August 19, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101021164730/http://charliehunter.com/discs/analogplayground.htm |archive-date=October 21, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.musicroom.com/se/ID_No/057413/details.html |title=The Peter Malick Group Featuring Norah Jones: New York City (PVG) at Musicroom.com \u2013 Sheet Music & Songbooks |publisher=Musicroom.com |date=October 23, 2003 |access-date=August 19, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.contactmusic.com/new/home.nsf/webpages/waxpoeticx23x02x04 |title=Wax Poetic \u2013 Set To Release New Album, Nublu Sessions \u2013 02/12/04 |magazine=Contactmusic.com |access-date=August 19, 2010}}</ref>\n\n===2000\u20132002: ''New York City'', ''First Sessions'' and ''Come Away with Me''===\n{{Main|New York City (The Peter Malick Group album)|First Sessions|Come Away with Me}}\nAs Peter Malick states in the liner notes, \"I started looking for a singer who might be open to recording [my latest songs] for me. On a Tuesday night, I walked into the Living Room just as the singer announced the last song of the set. The Dinah Washington classic 'Since I Fell for You' filled the room and I was struck breathless. Here, in the tradition of Billie Holiday, was a stunningly beautiful, blues infused voice. This was my first contact with Norah Jones.\"<ref name=\"NYC\">{{cite AV media notes |title=New York City |others=The Peter Malick Group featuring Norah Jones |date=May 2003 |last=Malick |first=Peter |type=CD liner notes |publisher=[[E1 Music|Koch Records]] |id=KOC-CD-8678}}</ref> Malick asked her to participate in sessions at Room 9 from Outer Space in [[South Boston]], during August and September 2000. They recorded Malick's songs \"New York City\", \"Strange Transmissions\", \"Deceptively Yours\" and \"Things You Don't Have to Do\" in addition to cover versions of \"All Your Love\" by Sam Maghett and \"Heart of Mine\" by Bob Dylan. These songs became the album ''New York City'' ([[Koch Records|Koch]], 2003) by the Peter Malick Group Featuring Norah Jones.<ref name=\"NYC\" />\n\nAfter moving to New York City, Jones signed to [[Blue Note Records|Blue Note]], a label owned by [[EMI Group]]. The signing came as an indirect result of her performing as lead singer for the JC Hopkins Biggish Band. Shell White, who was the wife of [[J. C. Hopkins]], worked for [[EMI Publishing]] and gave Jones's three-track demo to [[Bruce Lundvall]], the label's president, and Brian Bacchus, its artists and repertoire agent ([[artists and repertoire|A&R]]). The demo contained two jazz standards and a song by [[Jesse Harris]]. The two executives agreed that Jones had potential. Despite their misgivings about the direction of her music, they signed her to the label. Bacchus told ''[[HitQuarters]]'', \"We let her find her own direction&nbsp;... We knew that if she could develop her songwriting and we could find great songs, it would work.\"<ref name=\"hitquarters.com\">{{cite web |url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_BBacchus.html |title=Interview With Brian Bacchus |date=September 3, 2002 |website=[[HitQuarters]] |access-date=April 10, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190709132248/http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview%2Fopar%2Fintrview_BBacchus.html |archive-date=July 9, 2019 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n[[File:Norah Jones Cannes 1.jpg|right|thumb|upright|Jones at the premiere of ''My Blueberry Nights'' at the [[2007 Cannes Film Festival]]]]\nBacchus thought producer and engineer [[Jay Newland]]'s experience in jazz, blues, rock, country, and folk music would give a \"feeling for her sound.\" Jones and Newland recorded nine demo tracks. Four appeared on the sampler ''[[First Sessions]]'' (2001). The rest were set aside for her debut album.<ref name=\"hitquarters.com\" /> ''[[Come Away with Me]]'' (2002) was praised for its blend of acoustic pop with soul and jazz.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/rj9x/|title=BBC - Music - Review of Norah Jones - Come Away With Me|last=Shackleton|first=Kathryn|website=www.bbc.co.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=January 22, 2019}}</ref> Debuting at No.&nbsp;139, it reached No.&nbsp;1 on the U.S. [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. The single \"[[Don't Know Why]]\" hit No.&nbsp;1 on the [[Top 40 Adult]] Recurrents in 2003 and No.&nbsp;30 in the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 Singles Chart. At the 45th Grammy Awards in 2003, Jones was nominated for eight Grammy Awards and won five: [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]], [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]], [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Vocal Album|Best Pop Vocal Album]], [[Grammy Award for Record of the Year|Record of the Year]], and [[Grammy Award for Best Female Pop Vocal Performance|Best Female Pop Vocal Performance]] for \"Don't Know Why\". This tied [[Lauryn Hill]] and [[Alicia Keys]] for most Grammy Awards received by a female artist in one night. Jesse Harris won Song of the Year for \"Don't Know Why\" while [[Arif Mardin]] won [[Grammy Award for Producer of the Year, Non-Classical|Producer of the Year]]. The album won [[Grammy Award for Best Engineered Album, Non-Classical|Best Engineered Album, Non-Classical]].<ref name=\"CNN\" /> ''Come Away with Me'' was certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America ([[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]]) for having sold one million copies. In February 2005, it was certified diamond for selling ten million copies.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS |title=RIAA Searchable Database |publisher=Recording Industry Association of America |access-date=August 6, 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070626051113/http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS |archive-date=June 26, 2007 }}</ref>\n\n===2004\u20132009: ''Feels like Home'', ''Not Too Late'' and ''The Fall''===\n{{Main|Feels like Home (Norah Jones album)|Not Too Late (album)|The Fall (Norah Jones album)}}\n''[[Feels like Home (Norah Jones album)|Feels like Home]]'' (2004) debuted at the top of the charts in at least 16 countries, including Germany, New Zealand, and the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.emigroup.com/Press/2004/press3.htm |title=Norah Jones' follow-up 'Feels like Home' becomes million-seller \u2013 biggest first week for an album since 2001 (2004) |publisher=[[EMI]] |access-date=September 8, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081113100545/http://www.emigroup.com/Press/2004/press3.htm |archive-date=November 13, 2008}}</ref> At the [[47th Grammy Awards]] in 2005, the album was nominated for three Grammys, winning one, Best Female Pop Vocal Performance for \"[[Sunrise (Norah Jones song)|Sunrise]]\". For \"[[Here We Go Again (Ray Charles song)|Here We Go Again]]\", a duet with Ray Charles, she won Record of the Year and Best Pop Collaboration with Vocals.<ref>{{cite news |author=Tricia McDermott |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/2005-grammy-award-winners/ |title=2005 Grammy Award Winners |work=CBS News |date=February 13, 2005 |access-date=August 19, 2010}}</ref> ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine named Jones one of the most influential people of 2004.<ref>{{cite magazine |access-date=May 21, 2008 |url=http://www.time.com/time/subscriber/2004/time100/artists/100jones.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630171716/http://www.time.com/time/subscriber/2004/time100/artists/100jones.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=June 30, 2007 |title=Norah Jones |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |author=Farley, Christopher John |date=April 19, 2003}}</ref>\n\nJones released her third album, ''[[Not Too Late (album)|Not Too Late]]'', on January 30, 2007. The album was the first for which she wrote or co-wrote every song. She has said some of these songs are much darker than those on her previous albums.<ref>{{cite episode |title=Interview |series=[[60 Minutes]] |airdate=February 11, 2007}}</ref> ''Not Too Late'' was mostly recorded at Jones's home studio. It is her first album without producer Arif Mardin, who died in the summer of 2006. Jones described the sessions as \"fun, relaxed and easy\" and without a deadline; Blue Note executives reportedly did not know she was recording an album. The song \"My Dear Country\" is political commentary; she wrote it before the United States Presidential election day in 2004. ''Not Too Late'' reached the No.&nbsp;1 position in twenty countries. ''Not Too Late'' had the third-best first week of sales in 2007, behind [[Avril Lavigne]]'s ''[[The Best Damn Thing]]'' and [[Linkin Park]]'s ''[[Minutes to Midnight (Linkin Park album)|Minutes to Midnight]]''. It reached No.&nbsp;1 in the U.S., selling 405,000 copies. EMI announced that ''Not Too Late'' reached [[gold album|gold]], [[platinum album|platinum]] or multi-platinum in 21 countries as of February 2007.<ref>{{cite web |access-date=May 21, 2008 |url=http://www.emigroup.com/Press/2007/press6.htm |title=Norah Jones' ''Not Too Late'' debuts at No.&nbsp;1 in the world's key markets |publisher=[[EMI]] |date=February 7, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071211055309/http://www.emigroup.com/Press/2007/press6.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archive-date=December 11, 2007}}</ref> The album has sold 4 million copies worldwide. That same year she sang \"American Anthem\" for the [[Ken Burns]] documentary [[The War (2007 film)|''The War'']].<ref>{{cite news |title=Old Soldiers Never Lie |author=Beverly Gage |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/tv_week/2007/09/old_soldiers_never_lie.html |newspaper=Slate |date=September 20, 2007 |access-date=November 20, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Ken Burns' 'The War,' beginning Sunday on PBS |author=Neal Justin |url=http://seattletimes.com/html/television/2003893758_webkenburns20.html |newspaper=Seattle Times |date=September 20, 2007 |access-date=November 20, 2012}}</ref>\n\n[[File:Norahjonesongma (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|upright|Jones performing on ''[[Good Morning America]]'' in 2010.]]\nJones's fourth studio album, ''[[The Fall (Norah Jones album)|The Fall]]'', debuted at No. 3 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] in November 2009, selling 180,000 copies in its first week. Although it was her first album that did not reach No. 1 in the United States, it did receive critical acclaim.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/the-fall/norah-jones |title=Reviews for The Fall by Norah Jones |work=Metacritic|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|access-date=July 6, 2016}}</ref> As part of the promotional drive for the album, Jones performed on ''[[Dancing with the Stars]]'', ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'', ''[[Good Morning America]]'' and other television programs. ''The Fall'' featured a [[St. Bernard (dog)|St. Bernard]] on the cover; his name is Ben.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/article/2009/11/18/norah-jones-album-cover/|title=Norah Jones reveals her current listening and the identity of her CD cover canine costar|date=November 18, 2009|website=ew.com|access-date=July 11, 2017}}</ref> The album's [[lead single]], \"[[Chasing Pirates]]\", peaked at No.&nbsp;13 on [[Hot Adult Contemporary Tracks]] and No.&nbsp;7 on Jazz Songs. ''Billboard''{{'}}s 2000\u20132009 decade awards ranked Jones as the top jazz recording artist, at No.&nbsp;60 best Artist. ''Come Away With Me'' was elected the No.&nbsp;4 album and No.&nbsp;1 jazz album. \n\nJones earned a platinum certification by the [[RIAA]] for sales of 1 million copies of ''The Fall''. The album sold 1.5 million copies worldwide and was certified gold or platinum in 14 countries as of 2010. \"[[Baby, It's Cold Outside]]\", a duet with [[Willie Nelson]], was nominated in the Best Pop Collaboration with Vocals category. In 2009, Jones performed \"Come Away With Me\" and \"Young Blood\" at the end of the [[Apple Inc.]]'s It's Only Rock and Roll press conference on September 9 in San Francisco, for the release of iTunes 9 and video camera-equipped [[iPod]]s, among other items<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/171596/live_update_apples_rock_and_roll_event.html |title=Live Update: Apple's Rock & Roll Event |magazine=PCWorld |date=September 9, 2009 |access-date=August 19, 2010}}</ref> She also made a guest appearance and performed with other artists on the season three finale of the [[NBC]] series ''[[30 Rock]]''<ref>{{cite news |last=Itzkoff |first=Dave |url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/05/15/the-most-important-30-rock-clip-ever/ |title=The Most Important '30 Rock' Clip Ever |newspaper=NYTimes.com |date=May 15, 2009 |access-date=August 19, 2010}}</ref> Jones started her fourth world tour on March 5, 2010.\n\n===2012\u20132019: ''Little Broken Hearts'', ''Day Breaks'' and ''Begin Again''===\n{{Main|Little Broken Hearts|Day Breaks|Begin Again (Norah Jones album)}}\nAfter working with [[Danger Mouse (music producer)|Danger Mouse]] and [[Daniele Luppi]] on some of the tracks for their album ''[[Rome (Danger Mouse and Daniele Luppi album)|Rome]]'', Jones worked with Danger Mouse again on her fifth studio album, ''[[Little Broken Hearts]]'', which was released on May 1, 2012. She played the album in its entirety at [[South by Southwest|SXSW]] 2012.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Talbott |first1=Chris |title=Benny Labamba \u2014 Listening party: Norah Jones plays entire new album |url=http://bennylabamba.com/listening-party |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505163618/http://bennylabamba.com/listening-party |url-status=dead |archive-date=May 5, 2016 |website=archive.is |access-date=August 13, 2018 |date=March 19, 2014 }}</ref> ''[[American Songwriter]]'' called ''Little Broken Hearts'' the \"most dramatic and rewarding departure she's made in her career.\"<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2012/04/norah-jones-little-broken-hearts/ |title=Norah Jones: Little Broken Hearts |magazine=[[American Songwriter]] |access-date=April 19, 2012}}</ref> On May 25, 2012, she began her fifth world tour in Paris, with performances in Europe, North America, Asia, South America, and Australia. She performed in London at the [[Roundhouse (venue)|Roundhouse]] on September 10, 2012, as part of the [[iTunes Festival]] which was broadcast on the internet. She toured three cities in India for the first time because her father wanted her to do so. She also performed a headlining performance at Summer's Day, music festival produced by Only Much Louder. The tour started at Summer's Day in Mumbai on March 3 and included stops in New Delhi on March 5 and Bangalore on March 8.\n\nHer sixth studio album, ''[[Day Breaks]]'', which included nine new songs and three [[cover versions]], was released on October 7, 2016. \"Carry On\", the album's lead single, was released to digital outlets on the same day.<ref>{{cite magazine |first=Daniel |last=Kreps |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/hear-norah-jones-carry-on-off-new-lp-day-breaks-w432947 |title=Hear Norah Jones' 'Carry On,' First Single Off New LP 'Day Breaks' |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=August 5, 2016 |access-date=August 5, 2016}}</ref> The album marked a return to her piano after dabbling in folk and pop on the last two records. Jones said the goal of this record was to do everything live. She said in an interview with ''Billboard'', \"When you have great musicians, there's no reason to overdub. That strips the soul out of the music.\"<ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Ray|first1=Leigh Belz|title=Norah Jones Gets Candid About Married Life & Making Her New Album: 'The Goal Was to Do Everything Live' |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/magazine-feature/7525632/norah-jones-new-album-day-breaks|magazine=Billboard|date=September 29, 2016|access-date=October 21, 2016}}</ref> In 2019, Jones released a compilation album of singles she recorded from 2018 to 2019, entitled ''[[Begin Again (Norah Jones album)|Begin Again]]'' and the set includes collaborations with [[Jeff Tweedy]] and [[Doveman|Thomas Bartlett]].<ref>{{Cite web|date=2019-04-09|title=Album Review: Norah Jones Revels in Exploration on the Brief Begin Again|url=https://consequence.net/2019/04/album-review-norah-jones-begin-again/|access-date=2020-11-09|website=Consequence of Sound|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2019-04-10|title=Norah Jones: Begin Again Review|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/music/norah-jones/norah-jones-begin-again-review/|access-date=2020-11-09|website=pastemagazine.com|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/norah-jones-announces-experimental-new-project-begin-again-798815/|title=Norah Jones Announces Experimental New Project 'Begin Again'|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|last=Doyle|first=Patrick|date=February 22, 2019|accessdate=March 14, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brooklynvegan.com/tours-announced-norah-jones-sharon-van-etten-broken-social-scene-us-girls-more/|title=Tours announced: Norah Jones, Sharon Van Etten, Broken Social Scene, US Girls, more|website=[[BrooklynVegan]]|date=February 21, 2019|accessdate=March 14, 2019}}</ref>\n\n===2020\u2013present: ''Pick Me Up Off the Floor'', ''I Dream of Christmas'', and ''Visions'' ===\n{{Main|Pick Me Up Off the Floor|I Dream of Christmas|Visions (Norah Jones album)}}\nHer seventh studio album, ''[[Pick Me Up Off the Floor]]'', was released on June 12, 2020. It debuted at number 87 on the US ''Billboard'' 200, making it Jones's first album not to debut in the top three. Her eighth studio album, ''[[I Dream of Christmas]]'' was released in 2021,<ref name=Wood2024/> with an expanded version released in 2022.{{cn|date=August 2024}} In 2023, Jones was featured on rapper [[Logic (rapper)|Logic]]'s song \"Paradise II\" from his first independent studio album ''[[College Park (album)|College Park]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Logic Teams With Norah Jones, Details Shifting Priorities On New Song \"Paradise II\" |url=https://genius.com/a/logic-teams-with-norah-jones-details-shifting-priorities-on-new-song-paradise-ii |access-date=2023-05-19 |website=Genius |language=en}}</ref> In March 2024, Jones released her ninth studio album, ''[[Visions (Norah Jones album)|Visions]]'', produced by [[Leon Michels]]. The album is described by ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' as \"a funky, gently psychedelic garage-soul record\".<ref name=Wood2024/>\n\n==Additional projects and collaborations==\nJones made a cameo appearance as herself in the 2002 movie ''[[Two Weeks Notice]]'', which starred [[Hugh Grant]] and [[Sandra Bullock]]. The film shows her briefly at the piano, singing for a charity benefit.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0313737/fullcredits#cast |title=IMDB: Full cast and crew for Two Weeks Notice |website=[[Internet Movie Database]]}}</ref>\n\nIn 2003, [[Peter Malick|The Peter Malick Group]] and Jones released an album, ''[[New York City (The Peter Malick Group album)|New York City]]''. Jones appeared on [[OutKast]]'s ''[[Speakerboxxx/The Love Below]]'' album, on \"Take Off Your Cool\". This album won the Grammy Award for Album of the Year (Jones was not credited). Also in 2003, Jones appeared on [[Joel Harrison]]'s album of jazz interpretations of country and folk songs, ''[[Free Country (album)|Free Country]]'',<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://jazztimes.com/reviews/albums/joel-harrison-free-country/ |first=John|last=Murph|title=Joel Harrison: Free Country|magazine=[[JazzTimes]]|date=February 2004|page=123|access-date=February 27, 2017}}</ref> as lead vocalist on \"[[I Walk the Line]]\" and \"[[Tennessee Waltz]]\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/free-country-mw0000598347 |first=Scott|last=Yanow|title=Joel Harrison ''Free Country''|website=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=February 27, 2017}}</ref>\n\nJones formed [[The Little Willies]] in 2003, alongside Richard Julian on vocals, Jim Campilongo on guitar, Lee Alexander on bass, and Dan Rieser on drums. The [[country music|alt country]] band released its eponymous first album in 2006 and ''[[For The Good Times (The Little Willies album)|For the Good Times]]'' in 2012.<ref>{{cite web |last=Thomas |first=Stephen |url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r817856|pure_url=yes}} |title=The Little Willies > Overview |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=August 19, 2010}}</ref>\n\nJones appeared in the 2004 special, ''[[Sesame Street]] Presents: The Street We Live On''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0438410/ |title=Sesame Street Presents: The Street We Live On (2004) (TV) |website=[[Internet Movie Database]] |date=April 4, 2004 |access-date=December 11, 2007}}</ref> Jones appeared in the concert and DVD \"Return to Sin City \u2013 A Tribute to Gram Parsons\". Jones performed the song \"She\" and then, together with [[Keith Richards]] of [[The Rolling Stones]], sang \"Love Hurts\".\n\nIn 2005, Jones appeared on the [[Foo Fighters]]' album ''[[In Your Honor]]'', performing piano and vocals on the song \"Virginia Moon\".<ref>{{cite magazine |first=Barry |last=Walters |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/reviews/album/7733/38678 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100716190754/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/reviews/album/7733/38678 |url-status=dead |archive-date=July 16, 2010 |title=In Your Honor by Foo Fighters |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=June 30, 2005 |access-date=August 19, 2010}}</ref> The track was nominated for a Grammy for [[Best Pop Collaboration with Vocals]], in 2006.\n\nJones appeared on [[Ryan Adams]]' & [[The Cardinals (rock band)|The Cardinals]]' 2005 album, ''[[Jacksonville City Nights]]'', on the track \"Dear John\", which she co-wrote with Adams.<ref>{{cite magazine |first=Jenny |last=Eliscu |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/reviews/album/7733/38763 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130201112931/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/reviews/album/7733/38763 |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 1, 2013 |title=Jacksonville City Nights by Ryan Adams |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=October 6, 2005 |access-date=August 19, 2010 }}</ref> In 2011, Jones also played piano and vocals on numerous tracks on Ryan Adams' 2011 studio album ''[[Ashes & Fire]]''.\n\nJones worked with [[Mike Patton]] in 2006, providing vocals on the track \"Sucker\" on the [[Peeping Tom (band)|Peeping Tom]] project. The song attracted attention as it was the first time Jones used profanity in a recording.<ref>{{cite web |last=Harris |first=Chris |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1523855/20060207/jones_norah.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060901053738/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1523855/20060207/jones_norah.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 1, 2006 |title=Norah Jones Curses Up A Storm For New Mike Patton Project |publisher=MTV |date=February 10, 2006 |access-date=August 19, 2010}}</ref>\n\nIn 2007, Jones made her acting debut as the protagonist in a film directed by [[Wong Kar-wai]]. The film, ''[[My Blueberry Nights]]'', opened for the [[2007 Cannes Film Festival]] as one of the 22 films in competition.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0765120/|title=My Blueberry Nights (2007)|website=imdb.com|access-date=July 11, 2017}}</ref> She wrote and performed a song, \"The Story\", for the movie.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0765120/soundtrack |title=My Blueberry Nights (2007) \u2013 Soundtracks |website=[[Internet Movie Database]]}}</ref>\n\nIn January 2007, Jones recorded a live session at [[Abbey Road Studios]] for ''[[Live from Abbey Road]]''. The episode, on which [[John Mayer]] and [[Richard Ashcroft]] also appeared, was aired on UK [[Channel 4]] and on the [[Sundance Channel (United States)|Sundance Channel]]. She appeared twice on the [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] series ''[[Austin City Limits]]'', on November 2, 2002, and October 6, 2007. The latter appearance was the season opener.\n[[File:NorahJones Parque Independencia 2010.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Jones performing at [[Museu Paulista|Parque Independ\u00eancia]] in 2010]]\n\nIn a change of direction predating ''The Fall'', Jones (referring to herself as \"Maddie\" and virtually anonymous in a blond wig) sang and played guitar with rock band El Madmo. The band consists of Jones, [[Daru Oda]] and [[Richard Julian (Musician)|Richard Julian]] and released an eponymous album on May 20, 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogcritics.org/music/article/music-review-el-madmo-el-madmo/ |title=Music Review: El Madmo |publisher=[[Blogcritics.org]] |access-date=March 1, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100316095227/http://blogcritics.org/music/article/music-review-el-madmo-el-madmo/ |archive-date=March 16, 2010}}</ref>\n\nIn 2008, she recorded a duet with [[A Tribe Called Quest]] front man Q-Tip, titled \"Life Is Better\" from his \"Renaissance\" LP.\n\nJones appears in [[Herbie Hancock]]'s 2007 release ''[[River: The Joni Letters]]'', singing the first track, \"[[Court and Spark]]\". This album won the Grammy Award for Album of the Year at the [[50th Grammy Awards]] in 2008; Jones was credited as a featured artist, her ninth Grammy win.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/a-grammy-first-for-herbie-hancock/ |title=A Grammy First For Herbie Hancock |work=[[CBS News]] |date=February 4, 2008 |access-date=August 19, 2010}}</ref>\n\nJones is one of the participants in the so-called \"[[Hank Williams]] Project\" overseen by [[Bob Dylan]], and reportedly including contributions from Willie Nelson, [[Jack White (musician)|Jack White]], [[Lucinda Williams]], and [[Alan Jackson]].<ref>{{cite web |access-date=February 14, 2009 |url=http://www.expectingrain.com/discussions/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=26474 |title=The Hank Williams project |publisher=Expecting Rain}}</ref><ref name=\"Hollywood Insider\">{{cite web |access-date=February 14, 2009 |url=http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2008/04/dylan-jones-and.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080421051005/http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2008/04/dylan-jones-and.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=April 21, 2008 |title=Bob Dylan, Norah Jones put tunes to Hank Williams' lyrics |publisher=Hollywood Insider }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |access-date=February 14, 2009 |url=http://www.dreamtimepodcast.com/2008/01/episode-48-that-fateful-day-lost-songs.html |title=Dreamtime \u2013 Commentary on Bob Dylan's Theme Time Radio Hour |publisher=Dreamtime}}</ref> On March 31, 2008, Jones commemorated the 20th anniversary of [[The Living Room]] with a midnight performance at the intimate [[Manhattan]] music venue where the singer got her start. She played a new song entitled \"How Many Times Have You Broken My Heart\" and explained that it originated from newly found Hank Williams lyrics she was asked to put to music.<ref name=\"Hollywood Insider\" /> Jones also performed the song in late 2008 on [[Elvis Costello]]'s talk/music television series, ''[[Spectacle: Elvis Costello with...]]''.<ref>{{cite web |author=deerfried |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VWubsD8ZVNg | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130429013444/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VWubsD8ZVNg&gl=US&hl=en| archive-date=2013-04-29|title=How Many Times Have You Broke My Heart: Norah Jones |publisher=YouTube |date=February 3, 2009 |access-date=December 4, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elviscostello.info/wiki/index.php/TV_2008-09-15_Spectacle_(Rosanne_Cash,_Norah_Jones,_Kris_Kristofferson_%26_John_Mellencamp) |title=TV 2008-09-15 Spectacle (Rosanne Cash, Norah Jones, Kris Kristofferson & John Mellencamp) \u2013 The Elvis Costello Wiki |publisher=Elviscostello.info |access-date=December 4, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/smallscreen/news/article_1454756.php/Elvis_Costello_with_Kristofferson_Cash_Jones_and_Mellencamp |title=Elvis Costello with Kristofferson, Cash, Jones and Mellencamp |publisher=Monsters and Critics |date=January 21, 2009 |access-date=April 20, 2012}}</ref>\n\nJones was a judge for the 5th annual Independent Music Awards, supporting independent artists' careers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/pastjudges.asp |title=Independent Music Awards \u2013 Past Judges |publisher=The Independent Music Awards |access-date=October 28, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713024722/http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/pastjudges.asp |archive-date=July 13, 2011 }}</ref>\n\nIn 2010, Jones contributed \"World of Trouble\" to the [[Enough Project]] and [[Downtown Records]]' [https://web.archive.org/web/20120118191106/http://www.raisehopeforcongomusic.org/ ''Raise Hope for Congo''] compilation. Proceeds from the compilation fund efforts to make the protection and empowerment of Congo's women a priority, as well as inspire individuals around the world to raise their voices for peace in Congo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://enoughproject.org/press-releases/enough-project-and-mercer-street-records-present-raise-hope-congo|title=The Enough Project and Mercer Street Records Present: RAISE Hope for Congo \u2013 The Enough Project|website=enoughproject.org|date=June 8, 2010|language=en-US|access-date=May 26, 2017}}</ref>\n\nJones released ''[[...Featuring (Norah Jones album)|...Featuring]]'', a compilation album of collaborations she has done with well-known musicians, including the [[Foo Fighters]], Willie Nelson, [[Dirty Dozen Brass Band]], [[Outkast]], [[Q-Tip (rapper)|Q-Tip]], [[Talib Kweli]], [[Belle and Sebastian]], [[Ray Charles]], [[Ryan Adams]], Dolly Parton, [[Herbie Hancock]], [[M. Ward]], and others. Jones said, \"It's so exciting and flattering and fun when I get asked to sing with somebody that I admire.... It takes you a little bit out of your comfort zone when you're doing something with another artist. You don't know what to expect\u2014it's kind of like being a little kid and having a playdate.\" The 18-track Blue Note disc was released on November 16, 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bluenote.com/ArtistMain.aspx?ArtistId=908633 |title=Blue Note Records |publisher=[[Blue Note Records]] |access-date=December 28, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101212092429/http://bluenote.com/ArtistMain.aspx?ArtistId=908633 |archive-date=December 12, 2010}}</ref>\n\nJones recorded a Christmas duet, \"[[Home for the Holidays (song)|Home for the Holidays]]\", with [[Cyndi Lauper]].\n\nAs a tribute to [[Steve Jobs]], Jones performed a live three-song set at the Apple Campus in October 2011. It included \"Nearness of You\", \"Painter Song\", and Bob Dylan's \"[[Forever Young (Bob Dylan song)|Forever Young]]\". Forever Young was performed in honor of Jobs, because \"he liked Bob Dylan\".<ref>{{cite web | last=Updated | first=Last | title=Steve Jobs' memorial service: 6 highlights | website=The Week| date=2011-10-25 | url=https://theweek.com/articles/480739/steve-jobs-memorial-service-6-highlights | access-date=2024-04-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.macrumors.com/2011/10/19/norah-jones-and-coldplay-help-apple-celebrate-steve-jobs-life/ |title=Norah Jones and Coldplay Help Apple Celebrate Steve Jobs' Life |website=MacRumors |date=October 19, 2011 |access-date=October 19, 2011}}</ref>\n\nJones collaborated with ''[[Family Guy]]'' creator [[Seth MacFarlane]] on his Grammy-nominated 2011 debut studio album ''[[Music Is Better Than Words]]'' on the song \"[[Two Sleepy People]]\". Jones also had a cameo appearance in MacFarlane's 2012 feature film ''[[Ted (film)|Ted]]''. Additionally for the film, she collaborated with MacFarlane and ''Family Guy'' composer [[Walter Murphy]] on the song \"[[Everybody Needs a Best Friend]]\", recorded on the motion picture soundtrack album and nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Original Song]]. Jones would later collaborate with MacFarlane on his second studio album ''[[Holiday for Swing]]'' on the song \"Little Jack Frost Get Lost\".\n\nJones sang \"It Came Upon Midnight Clear\", \"Silent Night\" and \"Pooping Log (Caga Ti\u00f3)\" on the Holiday Special 2011 of ''[[Anthony Bourdain: No Reservations]]''.<ref>{{cite web |title=Anthony Bourdain: No Reservations: Holiday Special 2011 |url=http://www.travelchannel.com/tv-shows/anthony-bourdain/episodes/holiday |access-date=March 14, 2012}}</ref>\n\nIn September 2012, she appeared in \"30 Songs/30 Days\" to support ''[[Half the Sky: Turning Oppression into Opportunity for Women Worldwide]]'', a multi-platform media project inspired by Nicholas Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn's book.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.halftheskymovement.org/blog/entry/30-songs-30-days-for-half-the-sky1 |title=30 Songs / 30 Days for Half the Sky &#124; Half The Sky |publisher=Halftheskymovement.org |date=August 30, 2012 |access-date=September 17, 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121014103757/http://www.halftheskymovement.org/blog/entry/30-songs-30-days-for-half-the-sky1 |archive-date=October 14, 2012}}</ref>\n\nJones is featured on [[Robert Glasper]]'s 2013 album ''[[Black Radio 2]]'', singing \"Let It Ride\".\n\nIn October 2013, it was revealed that Jones and [[Green Day]] front man [[Billie Joe Armstrong]] would be releasing a duets LP. The album, consisting of covers from the [[The Everly Brothers|Everly Brothers]]' album ''[[Songs Our Daddy Taught Us]]'', was titled ''[[Foreverly]]'' and released on November 25, 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stereogum.com/1534781/qa-billie-joe-armstrong-norah-jones-unveil-duets-lp-hear-long-time-gone/franchises/interview/ |title=Q&A: Billie Joe Armstrong & Norah Jones Unveil Duets LP + Hear \"Long Time Gone\" |website=[[Stereogum]] |date=October 23, 2013 |access-date=November 25, 2013}}</ref> \n\nJones collaborated with her half-sister, [[Anoushka Shankar]], on Shankar's album ''[[Traces of You]]'', released on October 22, 2013. She contributed vocals to three songs on the album.\n\nJones recorded an album with her country music project, an all-female trio called [[Puss n Boots]], which consists of Jones, [[Sasha Dobson]] and [[Catherine Popper]]. The album, titled ''[[No Fools, No Fun]]'', was released on July 15, 2014, through Blue Note Records.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bluenote.com/news/puss-n-boots-announce-debut-album |title=PUSS N BOOTS ANNOUNCE DEBUT ALBUM \"NO FOOLS, NO FUN\" & TOUR DATES INCLUDING NEWPORT FOLK FESTIVAL |publisher=[[Blue Note Records]] |date=April 21, 2014 |access-date=April 22, 2014}}</ref>\n\nIn 2014, Jones played with her label-mates including [[Jason Moran (musician)|Jason Moran]], [[John Patitucci]], [[Brian Blade]] and [[Wayne Shorter]] in celebration of the 75th anniversary of Blue Note Records in the Concert Hall of [[John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/event/music/310772594/live-sunday-blue-note-at-75-the-concert |title=Blue Note at 75, The Concert |newspaper=NPR.org |publisher=NPR |access-date=November 9, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/event/music/315274268/blue-note-at-75-the-concert-norah-jones |title=Video: Norah Jones From Blue Note At 75, The Concert |website=NPR |date=May 28, 2014 |access-date=November 9, 2014|last1=Jarenwattananon |first1=Patrick }}</ref> Later, Jones joined [[Mavis Staples]] for two songs at the [[Newport Folk Festival]] to celebrate Staples' 75th birthday.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/2014/07/21/333725707/mavis-staples-live-in-concert-newport-folk-2014 |title=Mavis Staples, Live in Concert: Newport Folk 2014 |newspaper=NPR.org |publisher=NPR |access-date=November 9, 2014}}</ref>\n\nJones is featured on [[Harold Mabern]]'s 2014 album ''Afro Blue'', singing \"[[Fools Rush In (Where Angels Fear to Tread)|Fools Rush In]]\" and \"Don't Misunderstand\". On September 28, 2014, she appeared at the [[George Fest]] tribute concert to [[George Harrison]] in Los Angeles, where she sang \"[[Something (Beatles song)|Something]]\" and \"[[Behind That Locked Door]]\".<ref name=\"Volpert/PM\">{{cite magazine|first=Megan|last=Volpert|title=Various Artists: George Fest |url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/george-fest-by-various-artists-and-dhani-harrison/ |magazine=[[PopMatters]]|date=March 29, 2016|access-date=March 3, 2017}}</ref> Three days beforehand, Jones performed \"Behind That Locked Door\" live on the [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]] television show ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine|first=Ryan|last=Reed |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/watch-norah-jones-deliver-tasteful-george-harrison-cover-on-conan-20140926 |title=Watch Norah Jones Deliver Tasteful George Harrison Cover on 'Conan'|magazine=[[Rolling Stone|rollingstone.com]]|date=September 26, 2014|access-date=March 3, 2017}}</ref> Her performance at George Fest was included on the 2016 album and film release of the event.<ref name=\"Volpert/PM\" /><ref>{{cite magazine|first=Daniel |last=Kreps |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/all-star-george-harrison-tribute-concert-coming-to-cd-dvd-20151211 |title=All-Star George Harrison Tribute Concert Coming to CD/DVD |magazine=[[Rolling Stone|rollingstone.com]] |date=December 11, 2015 |access-date=March 3, 2017}}</ref>\n\nJones duets with The Rolling Stones' Keith Richards on the song \"Illusions\", from his 2015 album ''[[Crosseyed Heart]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine |first=Patrick |last=Doyle |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/keith-richards-talks-first-solo-lp-in-23-years-20150901 |title=Keith Richards Talks First Solo LP in 23 Years: 'Time Flies!' |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=September 1, 2015 |access-date=September 7, 2015}}</ref>\n\nOn May 6, 2015, Jones sang \"Don't Know Why\" on ''The Late Show with David Letterman'', as she had thirteen years before for her first appearance on the Letterman show. The episode was broadcast within two weeks of Letterman's retirement as host. During the same year, she sang \"[[Little Bird (The Beach Boys song)|Little Bird]]\" and \"[[God Only Knows]]\" at Brian Fest.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/review/6517044/norah-jones-flaming-lips-brian-wilson-festival |title=Norah Jones Out-Weirds The Flaming Lips at Brian Wilson Festival |last=Gallo |first=Phil |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=March 31, 2015 |access-date=May 21, 2015}}</ref>\n\nJones donated her voice to the end credits song from the film ''[[A Dog Named Gucci]]'', on the song \"One Voice\". The song also features singers [[Aimee Mann]], [[Susanna Hoffs]], [[Lydia Loveless]], [[Neko Case]], [[Kathryn Calder]] and [[Brian May]]. It was produced by Dean Falcone, who wrote the film's score. \"One Voice\" was released on [[Record Store Day]], April 16, 2016, with profits from the sale of the single going to benefit animal charities.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dvdandblu-rayreleasereport.blogspot.com/2016/03/filmmaker-gorman-bechards-dog-named.html |title=DVD & Blu-Ray Release Report: Filmmaker Gorman Bechard's A Dog Named Gucci To Make Its DVD Debut On Apr. 19 |last=Tribbey |first=Ralph |date=March 19, 2016 |website=DVD & Blu-Ray Release Report |access-date=April 12, 2016}}</ref>\n\nIn 2017, Jones recorded a rendition of \"[[Unchained Melody]]\", a song made famous by [[The Righteous Brothers]], for ''Resistance Radio: The Man in the High Castle Album'', a soundtrack to [[Amazon.com|Amazon]]'s ''[[The Man in the High Castle (TV series)|The Man in the High Castle]]'' TV series. The song and soundtrack were produced by [[Danger Mouse (musician)|Danger Mouse]], with whom Jones worked on her 2012 album, ''[[Little Broken Hearts]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine |first=Ryan |last=Reed |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/danger-mouse-recruits-beck-norah-jones-for-retro-covers-album-w470251 |title=Danger Mouse Recruits Beck, Norah Jones for Retro Covers Album |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=March 3, 2017 |access-date=April 11, 2017}}</ref>\n\n''Begin Again'' was released through [[Blue Note Records]] on April 12, 2019. The collection is a compilation of singles Jones recorded from 2018 to 2019, and includes collaborations with [[Jeff Tweedy]] and [[Doveman|Thomas Bartlett]]. Jones planned to tour Australia and the US in support of the album, before cancelling shows due to the [[COVID-19 pandemic]].\n\nIn 2020, Jones duetted with US jazz star [[Kandace Springs]] on the song \"[[Angel Eyes (1946 song)|Angel Eyes]]\" from her covers album ''The Women Who Raised Me''.\n\nFrom September 2022, Jones started a podcast called \"Norah Jones Is Playing Along\", where they played impromptu and improvised songs with a selection of guest artists including her half-sister [[Anoushka Shankar]], as well as [[Dave Grohl]], [[Marc Rebillet]] and more.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.norahjonesisplayingalong.com/|title=Norah Jones Is Playing Along Podcast|website=Norahjonesisplayingalong.com}}</ref>\n\nIn 2023, Jones was featured on the single \"Paradise II\" off of rapper [[Logic (rapper)|Logic]]'s eighth studio album ''College Park''.\n\nIn 2023, Jones collaborated with Icelandic jazz musician [[Laufey (singer)|Laufey]] on two tracks, recording a cover of the classic holiday song \"Have Yourself A Merry Little Christmas\" and releasing an original song titled \"Better Than Snow\".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://open.spotify.com/album/2cWrkknTj4squbs2aANuHp|title=Christmas With You|date=November 10, 2023|website=Open.spotify.com}}</ref>\n\n==Tours==\n* Come Away with Me Tour (2002\u201304)\n* Norah Jones & The Handsome Band Tour (2004\u201305) \n* Not Too Late Tour (2007\u201308)\n* The Fall Tour (2010)\n* [[Little Broken Hearts Tour]] (2012\u201313) \n* Daybreaks World Tour (2016\u201317) \n* North American Tour (2019)\n* Summer Tour (2022)<ref>{{cite web|last=Mergner|first=Lee|title=Norah Jones Announces Summer Tour|website=JazzTimes|date=2022-03-21|url=https://jazztimes.com/blog/norah-jones-announces-summer-tour/|access-date=2022-03-24}}</ref>\n* Visions Tour (2024)\n\n==Personal life==\nJones was in a relationship with bassist [[Lee Alexander (musician)|Lee Alexander]] from 2000 to 2007.<ref>{{cite web |access-date=November 14, 2009 |url=http://www.theinsider.com/news/568056_Norah_Jones_breaks_up_with_boyfriend_Lee_Alexander |title=Norah Jones and Lee Alexander Call it Quits |work=theinsider.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090319053938/http://www.theinsider.com/news/568056_Norah_Jones_breaks_up_with_boyfriend_Lee_Alexander |archive-date=March 19, 2009}}</ref> After a period of estrangement from her father, [[Ravi Shankar]], Jones traveled to [[New Delhi]] to spend time with him and wrote some material that was later recorded for the album ''The Fall''.<ref>{{cite news |last=McLean |first=Craig |title=Her Dark Materials: How Norah Jones Finally Exorcised Her Demons |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/her-dark-materials-how-norah-jones-finally-exorcised-her-demons-7678954.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220621/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/her-dark-materials-how-norah-jones-finally-exorcised-her-demons-7678954.html |archive-date=June 21, 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |access-date=November 20, 2012 |newspaper=The Independent |date=April 29, 2012}}</ref> Jones has two children with her husband, keyboardist Pete Remm.<ref name=Wood2024>{{cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/music/story/2024-03-04/norah-jones-new-album-visions-willie-nelson-joni-mitchell-my-dear-country-interview|title=Norah Jones on her surprising new album and the old song that's almost 'too sad' to play|last=Wood|first=Mikael|work=The Los Angeles Times|date=March 4, 2024|access-date=March 5, 2024|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Cashmere |first=Paul |title=Norah Jones Has Recorded a Song with Mavis Staples |work=Noise11 |date=October 4, 2019 |url=http://www.noise11.com/news/norah-jones-has-recorded-a-song-with-mavis-staples-20191004 |access-date=June 13, 2020 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=McRady |first=Rachel |title=Norah Jones Gives Birth to Her Second Child! |date=July 7, 2016 |work=[[Entertainment Tonight]] |url=http://www.etonline.com/news/192685_norah_jones_gives_birth_to_her_second_child/ |access-date=July 8, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160708132627/http://www.etonline.com/news/192685_norah_jones_gives_birth_to_her_second_child/ |archive-date=July 8, 2016 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |access-date=November 13, 2009 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8359542.stm |title=5 minutes with: Norah Jones |at=05:20 |publisher=BBC |date=November 14, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|title=Five Minutes With: Norah Jones| date=November 10, 2013 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y4pdMDkpUbA| an honorary Chairwoman of \"Save Fry Street\".\n* [[Indians in the New York City metropolitan area]]\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n{{sister project singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American folk singers]]\n[[Category:American Hindus]]\n[[Category:American jazz pianists]]\n[[Category:American jazz singers]]\n[[Category:American musicians of Indian North Texas College of Music alumni]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Lobo_(musician)","to":"Lobo (musician)"}],"pages":{"615031":{"pageid":615031,"ns":0,"title":"Lobo (musician)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2020}}\n{{BLP sources|date=July 2008}}\n{{For|the Dutch calypso singer Imrich Lobo|Lobo (Dutch singer)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Lobo\n| background       = solo_singer\n| image            = Lobo - TopPop 1973 04.png\n| caption          = Lobo in 1973\n| birth_name       = Roland Kent LaVoie\n| alias            = \n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1943|7|31}}  \n| birth_place           = [[Tallahassee, Florida]], U.S.\n| genre            = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[Folk music|folk]], [[folk rock]], [[soft rock]], [[Country music|country]]\n| occupation       = Singer-songwriter\n| instrument       = Vocals, guitarist\n| years_active     = 1961\u2013present\n| label            = [[Laurie Records|Laurie]], [[Big Tree Records|Big Tree]], [[MCA Records|MCA]], Lobo Records, [[Curb Records|Curb]], [[Pony Canyon]]\n| associated_acts  = [[The Rumours]] ([[Gram Parsons]], [[Jim Stafford]])\n| website          ={{URL|fansoflobo.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Roland Kent LaVoie''' (born July 31, 1943), better known by his stage name '''Lobo''' (which is Spanish for [[wolf]]), is an American singer-songwriter who was successful in the 1970s, scoring several U.S. Top 10 hits including \"[[Me and You and a Dog Named Boo]]\", \"[[I'd Love You to Want Me]]\", and \"[[Don't Expect Me to Be Your Friend]]\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicvf.com/Lobo.art|title=Lobo Songs (Top Songs/Chart Singles Discography)|publisher=Musicvf.com|access-date=May 8, 2011}}</ref> These three songs, along with \"[[Where Were You When I Was Falling in Love]]\", gave Lobo four chart toppers on the [[Adult Contemporary (chart)|Easy Listening/Hot Adult Contemporary]] chart.\n\n==Career==\n===1961\u20131970: Early years===\nBorn in [[Tallahassee, Florida]], LaVoie was raised by his mother in [[Winter Haven, Florida]], with his six siblings. He began his musical career in 1961 as a member of a local band, The Rumours. The band included [[Gram Parsons]] and [[Jim Stafford]], as well as drummer Jon Corneal, who later joined Parsons's [[International Submarine Band]].<ref name=BandBoxRecords>{{cite web|url=https://kimsloans.wordpress.com/tag/lobo-with-the-rumours-1960s-band-with-gram-parsons/|title=Lobo with the Rumours|website=PopBopRocktilUDrop|date=6 March 2021}}</ref>\n\nIn 1964, while attending the [[University of South Florida]], LaVoie joined a band called the Sugar Beats<ref name=BandBoxRecords /> and met producer [[Phil Gernhard]]. He recorded a regional hit for the band, a cover of [[Johnny Rivers]]'s song, \"What Am I Doing Here?\"<ref name=BandBoxRecords />\n\nDuring the 1960s, LaVoie performed with many other bands, including US Male, The Uglies, and Me and the Other Guys.<ref name=BandBoxRecords /> It was in the latter band that he met musician Billy Aerts, who became a member of Lobo's touring band in the early 1970s and produced Lobo's comeback album in 1989.\n\nAgain working with Gernhard, his first solo record was released in 1969 on [[Laurie Records]]. It included the original tracks \"Happy Days in New York City\" backed with \"My Friend Is Here\".\n\n===1971\u20131975: Success with Big Tree===\nBy 1971, LaVoie had started calling himself Lobo (Spanish for [[wolf]]). Gernhard was an executive for [[Big Tree Records]], and the company released his first single, \"[[Me and You and a Dog Named Boo]]\", in March 1971.  The first major hit for the label, it reached No. 5 in the US and No. 4 in the UK by May, launching a successful series of singles. It sold over one million copies and was awarded a [[music recording sales certification|gold disc]] in September 1971.<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\">{{cite book\n| first= Joseph\n| last= Murrells\n| year= 1978\n| title= The Book of Golden Discs\n| edition= 2nd\n| publisher= Barrie and Jenkins Ltd\n| location= London\n| page= [https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/297 297]\n| isbn= 0-214-20512-6\n| url-access= registration\n| url= https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/297\n}}</ref>\n\nHis debut album, ''Introducing Lobo'', came in  May 1971. In June his second single, \"She Didn't Do Magic\", was released. In September, \"California Kid and Reemo\" was released, followed by ''The Albatross''. When Big Tree Records merged with [[Bell Records]], Lobo's second project album ''Close Up'' was never released.\n\nUnder the Lobo alias, he then released ''Of a Simple Man'' in 1972, which included back-to-back U.S. Top 10 hits, including \"[[I'd Love You to Want Me]]\" (No. 2, November 18\u201325, 1972) and \"[[Don't Expect Me to Be Your Friend]]\" (No. 8, February 17\u201324, 1973).  The former became Lobo's biggest hit, a million-seller gaining gold disc status in November 1972<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\"/> and internationally reaching No. 1 in Germany in December 1973 and No. 5 in the United Kingdom in July 1974.\n\nWith the release of ''Calumet'' in 1973, Lobo had three more [[Top 40]] hits: \"It Sure Took a Long, Long Time\", \"[[How Can I Tell Her]]\", and \"Standing at the End of the Line\". He made an appearance on ''[[American Bandstand]]'' that year. There were two further minor hit singles from the album: \"There Ain't No Way\" and \"Love Me for What I Am\".\n\nIn June 1974 Lobo's fourth album, ''Just a Singer'', was released. It was the first album by Lobo to contain tracks not written by him. The only single from the album was \"Rings\". \"Don't Tell Me Goodnight\" in 1975 became his last Top 30 single for Big Tree. Lobo also released the album, ''A Cowboy Afraid of Horses'', with \"Would I Still Have You\" released as a single. The label followed it up with a compilation album that year entitled ''The Best of Lobo''.\n\n===1976\u20131985: Curb Records, and move to Nashville===\nIn 1976 Lobo broke away from Big Tree, releasing the album ''Come with Me'' in Europe on the [[Philips Records|Philips]] label.  \"At First Sight\" and \"It's Everywhere\" were the singles.  Neither was released in the US.\n\nLobo signed with [[Curb Records]] in 1977, releasing the single \"Afterglow\", co-produced by Lobo and Gernhard, and in 1978 \"You Are All I'll Ever Need\".  No full-length album materialized from these sessions.\n\nIn 1979 Lobo was signed to Curb/[[MCA Records]], where he worked with producer [[Bob Montgomery (musician)|Bob Montgomery]], releasing the single \"Where Were You When I Was Falling in Love\", which reached No. 23.  The song also reached No. 1 on the Adult Contemporary chart.  He also released his first US album in four years, ''Lobo''. Other singles for Curb were \"Holding On for Dear Love\", \"With a Love Like Ours\", and \"Fight Fire with Fire\".\n\nReportedly dissatisfied with the production of his records, Lobo sought a release from his Curb contract.  He moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] and, in 1981, started his [[Private brand|own label]], Lobo Records, releasing several singles including \"I Don't Want to Want You\" (written by his brother, Roger LaVoie), \"Come Looking for Me\", and \"Living My Life Without You\", all of which charted in the country charts.  He also released \"Bull Smith Can't Dance the Cotton Eye Joe\" with the group Wolfpack, which included Narvel Felts and Kenny Earl.\n\nLobo Records was renamed Evergreen Records in 1985.  The label released two of his singles: \"Am I Going Crazy\" and \"Paint the Town Blue\", the latter a duet with Robin Lee.\n\n===1987\u2013present: Asian popularity and recent years===\nAlthough he is far less followed now in the United States, Lobo's popularity grew in Asia, fanned by the release of his [[greatest hits]] compilations in 1987 and 1988. This encouraged him to release in 1989 his first new album in 10 years, entitled ''Am I Going Crazy''. It was recorded in [[Taiwan]] on UFO/WEA Records and was produced by Billy Aerts. He signed a multi-album deal with PonyCanyon Records in Singapore, and in 1994 released ''Asian Moon'', repackaging some of the tracks from ''Am I Going Crazy'' along with newly recorded material. His follow-up album ''Classic Hits'' in 1995 were re-recordings of Lobo hits and some [[cover version]]s. In 1996 he released the album ''Sometimes'', containing all new original songs.\n\nOn another Asian label, Springroll Entertainment, he released ''You Must Remember This'' in 1997, an album of [[pop standards]] that was released in two formats, one with vocals and the other with instrumental tracks.\n\nIn 2000, Lobo signed with a German record company, Gmbh Entertainment, and recorded a few tracks for various hits CDs. He also co-wrote two [[Christmas music|Christmas songs]] with Billy Aerts, \"A Big Kid's Christmas\" and \"Late Christmas Eve\", which have been released on various Christmas compilations from 2000 to present. Singles recorded during this period include \"[[Let It Be Me (The Everly Brothers song)|Let It Be Me]]\", \"Who'll Stop the Rain\", and \"Different Drum\".\n\nIn 2006, based on his Asian popularity, he toured in Southeast Asia. In 2008, Lobo released ''Out of Time'' with old favorites and some new songs. A tribute album to the original era of the early Lobo recordings was made available from the website.\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! 13\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1980\n| style=\"text-align:left;\"| \"With a Love Like Ours\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| Billboard unless otherwise noted. * Cash Box singles chart.<ref name=\"Whitburn\">{{cite book| last = Whitburn| first = Joel| title = The Comparison Book Billboard/Cash Box/Record World 1954\u20131982| publisher = Sheridan Books| year = 2015| isbn = 978-0-89820-213-7|page=307}}</ref>\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{Official website}}\n*{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p4774|label=Lobo}}\n* {{discogs artist|Lobo (3)}}\n* {{IMDb name|2499367}}\n\n{{Lobo (musician)|state=expanded}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Lobo}}\n[[Category:1943 births]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male pop singers]]\n[[Category:American rock singers]]\n[[Category:American rock songwriters]]\n[[Category:American soft rock musicians]]\n[[Category:Bell Records artists]]\n[[Category:Big Tree Records artists]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:MCA Records artists]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Tallahassee, Florida]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Florida]]\n[[Category:University of South Florida alumni]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:20th-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Sue_Thompson","to":"Sue Thompson"}],"pages":{"8306149":{"pageid":8306149,"ns":0,"title":"Sue Thompson","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer (1925\u20132021)}}\n{{for|the Scottish pool player|Sue Thompson (pool player)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist|<!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name             = Sue Thompson\n| image            = File:Sue Thompson - Cash Box 1962.png\n| caption          = Thompson on the cover of ''[[Cashbox (magazine)|Cash Box]]'', 1962\n| image_size       = <!-- Only for images smaller than 220 pixels -->\n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = Eva Sue McKee\n| birth_date       = {{Birth date|1925|7|19}}\n| birth_place      = [[Nevada, Missouri]], U.S.\n| death_date       = {{Death date and age|2021|9|23|1925|7|19}}\n| death_place      = [[Pahrump, Nevada]], U.S.\n| genre            = [[Pop (music)|Pop]], [[Country music|country]]\n| occupation       = [[Singing|Singer]]\n| instrument       = Vocals\n| years_active     = 1950\u20131990s\n| label            = {{hlist|[[Mercury Records|Mercury]]|[[Decca Records|Decca]]|[[Columbia Records|Columbia]]|[[Hickory Records|Hickory]]}}\n| associated_acts  = \n}}\n\n'''Sue Thompson''' (born '''Eva Sue McKee'''; July 19, 1925 \u2013 September 23, 2021) was an American pop and country music singer. She is best known for the million selling 1961 hits \"[[Sad Movies (Make Me Cry)]]\" and \"[[Norman (song)|Norman]]\", \"James (Hold The Ladder Steady)\" (1962), and \"Paper Tiger\" (1965).\n\n==Early life==\nThompson was born in [[Nevada, Missouri]] in July 1925. By the age of 7, she was singing and playing the guitar on stage.  She later moved with her family to live in [[San Jose, California]].<ref name=allmusic>{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1836/biography|pure_url=yes}} Sue Thompson biography at Allmusic</ref>\n\nDuring [[World War II]], she worked at a defense plant.  She married when she was 17, and had a daughter at 20, but the marriage failed and she and her husband split up after three years. To keep supporting herself after her divorce, she returned to the [[nightclub]] scene in [[California]], now using the name Sue Thompson. In San Jose, she won a talent contest, thus catching the attention of a bandleader and radio/TV host named Dude Martin (real name John Stephen McSwain), who invited her to sing with his band. This led to their marriage.<ref name=kienzle>{{cite book |last=Kienzle |first=Rich |author-link= |date=2013 |title=Southwest Shuffle|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WFf_RbP6xlsC&dq=%22Hank+Penny%22+%22Sue+Thompson%22&pg=PA50 |location= |publisher= Taylor & Francis|pages=50\u201351 |isbn=9781136718892}}</ref> They recorded duets together, including \"If You Want Some Lovin'\", which helped her get a solo contract from [[Mercury Records]] in 1950.<ref name=allmusic/>  She released numerous singles on Mercury between 1951 and 1954, with no chart action.\n\n==Recording career==\nWithin a year, she divorced Martin, and married [[Hank Penny]], a comedian and singer, in 1953.<ref name=kienzle/>  Penny and Thompson hosted a TV show in [[Los Angeles]] together before eventually moving to [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]]. After her contract with Mercury ended, Thompson recorded for [[Decca Records]] from 1954\u201357, again without a commercial breakthrough.   Thompson and Penny had a son, [[Greg Penny]], but divorced in 1963.<ref name=kienzle/>\n\nIn 1960, Thompson signed on with [[Columbia Records]], who renamed the singer \"Taffy Thomas\" and issued one non-charting single under this artist name.  Thereafter, the Taffy Thomas moniker was quickly dropped, and Thompson signed with [[Hickory Records]]. In 1961, after having issued over a dozen non-charting singles in a decade-long recording career, Thompson's \"[[Sad Movies (Make Me Cry)]]\" became a No.&nbsp;5 hit on the [[Pop (music)|pop]] charts.  She followed this up successfully with \"[[Norman (song)|Norman]],\" which reached No.&nbsp;3. Both of these hit singles were written by [[songwriter]] [[John D. Loudermilk]]. They both sold over one million copies, and were awarded [[music recording sales certification|gold discs]]. Both were also chart successes in Australia, reaching #3 and #8 respectively.<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\">{{cite book| first= Joseph| last= Murrells| year= 1978| title= The Book of Golden Discs| edition= 2nd| publisher= Barrie and Jenkins Ltd| location= London| page= [https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/140 140]| isbn= 0-214-20512-6| url-access= registration| url= https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/140}}</ref>\n\nIn 1962, \"Have a Good Time\" was a Top 40 hit and in 1963, \"Willie Can\" was a minor hit.  Her early-1960s hits made Thompson, then in her late-thirties but with a much younger-sounding voice, a favorite among the teenage crowd and briefly a rival to the much younger [[Connie Francis]] and [[Brenda Lee]].<ref name=allmusic/> Two additional hits, also written by Loudermilk, were \"James (Hold the Ladder Steady)\", and 1965's \"Paper Tiger,\" her last Top 30 hit and her biggest hit in Britain and in Australia, where it reached #3.\n\n==Later career==\nIn the late 1960s, she went back to country music and released the album ''This Is Sue Thompson Country'' in 1969.<ref>[https://www.allmusic.com/album/this-is-sue-thompson-country-mw0000891899 This Is Sue Thompson Country Album Information]. ''AllMusic''. Retrieved 13 October 2021.</ref> Her single''Thoughts'' with Roy Acuff Jr. reached #39 on the Canadian Country charts, November 8, 1969.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/obj/028020/f2/nlc008388.100198.pdf| title=RPM Top 50 Country - November 8, 1969}}</ref>  In 1971 she worked with [[country music]] [[singing|singer]] [[Don Gibson]] on some albums, and they had minor hits with \"I Think They Call It Love\", \"Good Old Fashioned Country Love\", and \"Oh, How Love Changes\". She recorded further solo singles for the [[Country music|country]] charts, like \"Big Mable Murphy\", which made the Top 50 in 1975 and \"Never Naughty Rosie\", her last chart single in 1976. She also performed mainly at the [[Las Vegas Strip|Las Vegas]] casinos and at clubs in [[Hollywood, Los Angeles|Hollywood]], like the ''Palomino Club''. In the 1990s, she settled in [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]], and continued to periodically perform.<ref name=allmusic/>\n\nShe also appeared on ''[[American Bandstand]]'', ''[[Where the Action Is]]'', ''[[The Buddy Deane Show]]'', and ''[[The Lloyd Thaxton Show]]'' (1966 visit and performance of \"Paper Tiger\").{{citation needed|date=September 2021}}\n\nIn 2009 Thompson's son, record producer Greg Penny, recorded her acoustic cover of her favourite song, the 1952 hit \"[[You Belong to Me (1952 song)|You Belong to Me]]\".<ref name=\"nytimes.com\">{{cite news |title=Sue Thompson, Who Sang of 'Norman' and Sad Movies, Dies at 96 |first=Neil |last=Genzlinger |author-link=Neil Genzlinger |date=2021-09-28 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/09/28/arts/music/sue-thompson-dead.html |access-date=2021-09-28 |url-access=subscription}}</ref> The demo was given its radio premiere during her 2010 interview on the South Australian radio show \"The Doo Wop Corner\" by Carmen Kaye.<ref name=\"nytimes.com\"/>\n\n==Death==\nSue Thompson died at her daughter's home in [[Pahrump, Nevada]], on September 23, 2021, at the age of 96.<ref name=\"nytimes.com\"/><ref>[https://www.noise11.com/news/sue-thompson-dies-at-age-96-20210928  Paul Cashmere, \"Sue Thompson Dies At Age 96\", ''Noise11'', September 28, 2021]. Retrieved September 28, 2021</ref><ref>[https://www.savingcountrymusic.com/oldest-living-country-music-legend-sue-thompson-dead-at-96/ Oldest Living Country Music Legend Sue Thompson Dead at 96]</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n! colspan=\"2\"| Chart Positions\n|-\n! style=\"width:50px;\"|
