Sheeran"}],"pages":{"30528002":{"pageid":30528002,"ns":0,"title":"Ed Sheeran","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|English singer-songwriter (born 1991)}}\n{{pp-blp|small=yes}}\n{{Use British English|date=December 2017}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2023}}\n{{Infobox person\n| name               = Ed Sheeran\n| honorific_suffix   = {{post-nominals|size=100%|country=GBR|MBE}}\n| image              = Ed Sheeran-6886 (cropped).jpg\n| caption            = Sheeran in 2018\n| birth_name         = Edward Christopher Sheeran\n| education          = [[Framlingham College|Brandeston Hall]]<br>[[Thomas Mills High School]]\n| birth_date         = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1991|2|17}}\n| birth_place        = [[Halifax, West Yorkshire]], England\n| occupation         = {{flatlist|\n* Singer-songwriter\n* musician\n* record producer\n* actor\n}}\n| years_active       = 2004\u2013present\n| spouse             = {{marriage|Cherry Seaborn|2019}}\n| children           = 2\n| awards             = [[List of awards and nominations received by Ed Sheeran|Full list]]\n| website            = {{URL|edsheeran.com}}\n| module             = {{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->|embed=yes\n| instrument   = {{flatlist|\n* Vocals\n* guitar<ref name=\"archive1\">{{cite web |url=https://www.mtv.com/news/n4kmwp/ed-sheeran-tells-you-101-things-you-didnt-know-but-need-to-know-about-him |title=Ed Sheeran Hates Kale, Speaks German And 99 Other Things You Probably Didn't Know About Him |publisher=[[MTV]] |date=9 June 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220826165621/https://www.mtv.com/news/n4kmwp/ed-sheeran-tells-you-101-things-you-didnt-know-but-need-to-know-about-him |access-date=26 August 2022 |archive-date=26 August 2022 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n<!-- only commonly used instruments -->\n}}\n| genre        = {{flatlist|\n* [[Pop music|Pop]]\n* [[folk-pop]]\n* [[soft rock]]\n}}\n| label        = {{flatlist|\n* [[Asylum Records|Asylum]]\n* [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]\n* [[Elektra Records|Elektra]]\n* [[Gingerbread Man Records|Gingerbread Man]]\n}}\n| associated_acts = {{flatlist|\n* [[Taylor Swift]]\n* [[Benny Blanco]]\n* [[Jake Gosling]]\n* [[Fred Again]]\n* [[Steve Mac]]\n* [[Justin Bieber]]\n* [[Eminem]]\n* [[Yelawolf]]\n* [[Stormzy]]\n* [[Amy Wadge]]\n* [[Anne Marie]]\n* [[Elton John]]\n* [[Fireboy]]\n* [[Russ (rapper)|Russ]]\n}}\n}}\n}}\n\n'''Edward Christopher Sheeran''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|MBE}} ({{IPAc-en|\u02c8|\u0283|\u026a\u0259r|\u0259n}} {{respell|SHEER|\u0259n}}; born 17 February 1991) is an English singer-songwriter. Born in [[Halifax, West Yorkshire]], and raised in [[Framlingham, Suffolk]], he began writing songs around the age of eleven. In early 2011, Sheeran independently released the extended play ''[[No. 5 Collaborations Project]]''. He signed with [[Asylum Records]] the same year.\n\nSheeran's debut album, ''[[+ (album)|+]]'' (\"''Plus''\"), was released in September 2011 and topped the [[UK Albums Chart]]. It contained his first hit single \"[[The A Team (Ed Sheeran song)|The A Team]]\". In 2012, Sheeran won the [[Brit Awards]] for [[Brit Award for British Male Solo Artist|Best British Male Solo Artist]] and [[Brit Award for British Breakthrough Act|British Breakthrough Act]]. Sheeran's second studio album, ''[[x (Ed Sheeran album)|\u00d7]]'' (\"''Multiply''\"), topped charts around the world upon its release in June 2014. It was named the second-best-selling album worldwide of 2015. In the same year, ''\u00d7'' won [[Brit Awards 2015#Nominees and winners|Album of the Year]] at the [[2015 Brit Awards]], and he received the [[Ivor Novello Awards|Ivor Novello Award]] for Songwriter of the Year from the [[British Academy of Songwriters, Composers and Authors]]. A single from ''\u00d7'', \"[[Thinking Out Loud]]\", earned him the 2016 [[Grammy Award]]s for [[Grammy Award for Song of the Year|Song of the Year]] and [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Solo Performance|Best Pop Solo Performance]].\n\nSheeran's third album, ''[[\u00f7 (album)|\u00f7]]'' (\"''Divide''\"), was released in March 2017, and was the [[List of best-selling albums#Best-selling album by year worldwide|best-selling album worldwide of 2017]]. The first two singles from the album, \"[[Shape of You]]\" and \"[[Castle on the Hill]]\", broke records in a number of countries by debuting in the top two positions of the charts. He also became the first artist to have two songs debut in the US top 10 in the same week. By March 2017, Sheeran had accumulated ten top-10 singles from ''\u00f7'' on the [[UK Singles Chart]], breaking the record for most top-10 UK singles from one album. His fourth single from ''\u00f7'', \"[[Perfect (Ed Sheeran song)|Perfect]]\", reached number one in the US, Australia, and the UK, where it became the [[List of UK Singles Chart Christmas number ones|Christmas number one]] in 2017. The world's best-selling artist of 2017, he was named the [[Global Recording Artist of the Year]]. Released in 2019, his fourth overall and first collaborative album, ''[[No.6 Collaborations Project]]'', debuted at number one in most major markets, and spawned three UK number one singles, \"[[I Don't Care (Ed Sheeran and Justin Bieber song)|I Don't Care]]\", \"[[Beautiful People (Ed Sheeran song)|Beautiful People]]\", and \"[[Take Me Back to London]]\". His fifth studio album, ''[[= (album)|=]]'' (\"''Equals''\"), topped the charts in most major markets in 2021. His sixth album, ''[[- (album)|-]]'' (\"''Subtract''\"), was released on 5 May 2023, while his seventh album, ''[[Autumn Variations]]'', was released on 29 September 2023 under his own record label, Gingerbread Man Records.\n\nSheeran has sold more than 150 million records worldwide, making him one of the [[List of best-selling music artists|world's best-selling music artists]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/lifestyle/solo-party-ed-sheeran-releases-album-while-isolating-covid-2021-10-29/|title='Solo party': Ed Sheeran releases album while isolating for COVID|work=[[Reuters]]|date=29 October 2021|access-date=29 October 2021|archive-date=16 August 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220816094522/https://www.reuters.com/lifestyle/solo-party-ed-sheeran-releases-album-while-isolating-covid-2021-10-29/|url-status=live}}</ref> He has 101 million [[RIAA]]-certified units in the US,<ref>{{cite news |title=Gold & Platinum |website=[[RIAA]] |url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/ |access-date=29 June 2020 |archive-date=12 February 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180212231947/https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/ |url-status=live }}</ref> and two of his albums are in the list of the [[List of best-selling albums in the United Kingdom|best-selling albums in UK chart history]]. In December 2019, the [[Official Charts Company]] named him artist of the decade, with the most combined success in the UK album and singles charts in the 2010s.<ref name=\"Decade\">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-50732153 |title=Ed Sheeran named 'artist of the decade' |date=11 December 2019 |work=[[BBC News]] |access-date=11 December 2019 |archive-date=11 December 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191211082444/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-50732153 |url-status=live }}</ref> As of July 2024, he is the 3rd most followed artist on [[Spotify]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://volt.fm/most-followed-artists|title=Most followers on Spotify|date=29 July 2024|website=volt.fm|access-date=29 July 2024}}</ref> Beginning in March 2017, his [[\u00f7 Tour]] became the [[List of highest-grossing concert tours|highest-grossing of all time]] in August 2019. An alumnus of the [[National Youth Theatre]] in London, Sheeran's acting roles include appearing in the 2019 film ''[[Yesterday (2019 film)|Yesterday]]'', playing himself. \n\n== Early life and education ==\n[[File:Franglingham Castle 01.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|[[Framlingham Castle]] in Sheeran's home town. The castle and his upbringing in Framlingham is the subject of his 2017 single \"[[Castle on the Hill]]\".<ref>{{cite web|last=Adejobi|first=Alicia|title=Inside the real Castle On The Hill where Ed Sheeran 'found love' and 'got drunk'|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/inside-real-castle-hill-where-ed-sheeran-found-love-got-drunk-1600101|website=International Business Times UK|access-date=11 January 2017|date=9 January 2017|archive-date=13 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170113133637/http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/inside-real-castle-hill-where-ed-sheeran-found-love-got-drunk-1600101|url-status=live}}</ref>]]\nEdward Christopher Sheeran was born on 17 February 1991 in [[Halifax, West Yorkshire]], England.<ref name=allmusicbio>{{cite web| url = https://www.allmusic.com/artist/ed-sheeran-mn0002639628/biography| title = Ed Sheeran Biography| first = Jon| last = O'Brien| website = [[AllMusic]]| access-date = 10 December 2015| archive-date = 26 May 2019| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20190526141635/https://www.allmusic.com/artist/ed-sheeran-mn0002639628/biography| url-status = live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hebdenbridgetimes.co.uk/whats-on/music/halifax-born-singer-ed-sheeran-wins-top-award-1-7001208|title=Halifax-born singer Ed Sheeran wins top award|date=12 December 2014|work=The Hebden Bridge Times|access-date=16 March 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170317143550/http://www.hebdenbridgetimes.co.uk/whats-on/music/halifax-born-singer-ed-sheeran-wins-top-award-1-7001208|archive-date=17 March 2017|url-status=dead}}</ref> His early childhood home was on Birchcliffe Road in nearby [[Hebden Bridge]].<ref name=earlyhome>{{cite web | url = https://www.elmetfarmhouse.co.uk/10-fascinating-facts-about-funky-hebden-bridge/ | title = 10 Fascinating Facts about Funky Hebden Bridge | access-date = 25 February 2019 | first = Lesley | last = Jackson | date = 22 February 2016 | work = Elmet Farmhouse | quote = World-famous singer songwriter Ed Sheeran spent his formative early childhood years in Hebden Bridge and seems to have absorbed its quirky, independent spirit. | archive-date = 25 February 2020 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20200225071845/https://www.elmetfarmhouse.co.uk/10-fascinating-facts-about-funky-hebden-bridge/ | url-status = live }}</ref> His father was a curator at [[Cartwright Hall]] in [[Bradford]], and his mother worked at [[Manchester City Art Gallery]].<ref name=earlyhome/><ref>{{Cite news |last=Russell |first=Sam |date=29 September 2022 |title=Ed Sheeran's father shares details of his life in art in speech at charity event |language=en-GB |work=Belfast Telegraph |url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/music/news/ed-sheerans-father-shares-details-of-his-life-in-art-in-speech-at-charity-event/42026078.html |access-date=26 November 2023 |issn=0307-1235 |archive-date=26 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231126100650/https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/music/news/ed-sheerans-father-shares-details-of-his-life-in-art-in-speech-at-charity-event/42026078.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=29 September 2022 |title=Ed Sheeran's father shares details of his life in art in speech at charity event |url=https://www.irishnews.com/magazine/entertainment/2022/09/29/news/ed_sheeran_s_father_shares_details_of_his_life_in_art_in_speech_at_charity_event-2843968/ |access-date=16 November 2023 |website=The Irish News |language=en |archive-date=26 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231126095544/https://www.irishnews.com/magazine/entertainment/2022/09/29/news/ed_sheeran_s_father_shares_details_of_his_life_in_art_in_speech_at_charity_event-2843968/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In December 1995, he moved with his family from Hebden Bridge to [[Framlingham]] in [[Suffolk]],<ref>{{cite book |last=Smith |first=Sean |title=Sheeran: A Biography |date=2019 |publisher=Diversion Books}}</ref><ref name=\"TheInd-Walsh\">{{cite news|last=Walsh|first=John|date=6 December 2014|title=Ed Sheeran: Boy next door who made it very big|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/ed-sheeran-boy-next-door-who-made-it-very-big-9907243.html|work=[[The Independent]]|access-date=8 November 2015|archive-date=15 January 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180115160407/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/ed-sheeran-boy-next-door-who-made-it-very-big-9907243.html|url-status=live}}</ref> where he attended the independent [[Brandeston Hall]] [[Preparatory school (United Kingdom)|preparatory school]] (now [[Framlingham College]] Prep School),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/article/ed-sheeran-new-album-divide|title=How Ed Sheeran became the biggest male popstar on the planet|date=2 February 2017|website=British GQ|access-date=27 August 2022|archive-date=24 January 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220124024832/https://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/article/ed-sheeran-new-album-divide|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oldframlinghamian.com/article.php?story=20170124172421166|title=Ed Sheeran meets best mate from Brandeston Hall on Graham Norton Show - OldFramlinghamian.com|website=oldframlinghamian.com|access-date=27 August 2022|archive-date=25 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211025214229/http://www.oldframlinghamian.com/article.php?story=20170124172421166|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.framlinghamcollege.co.uk/cocurricular/music/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200814111116/https://www.framlinghamcollege.co.uk/cocurricular/music/|url-status=dead|archive-date=14 August 2020|title=Music|date=14 August 2020}}</ref> then [[Thomas Mills High School]], also in Framlingham.<ref name=\"auto\">{{cite news |author=Rock and Pop Features |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopfeatures/8679492/Ed-Sheeran-I-havent-got-used-to-the-screams.html |title=Ed Sheeran: 'I haven't got used to the screams' |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=3 August 2011 |access-date=8 June 2013 |location=London |archive-date=17 June 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180617211441/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopfeatures/8679492/Ed-Sheeran-I-havent-got-used-to-the-screams.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=\"intro\">{{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/suffolk/content/articles/2008/04/22/introducing_ed_sheeran_feature.shtml | title = Introducing \u2013 Ed Sheeran | publisher = [[BBC Suffolk]] | access-date = 11 August 2011 | date = April 2008 | archive-date = 11 January 2018 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180111084619/http://www.bbc.co.uk/suffolk/content/articles/2008/04/22/introducing_ed_sheeran_feature.shtml | url-status = live }}</ref> He has an older brother named Matthew, who works as a composer.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chart Beat Podcast: Matt Sheeran on Working With Brother Ed, & Andrea Bocelli, on 'Perfect' |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/podcasts/8097573/matt-sheeran-ed-sheeran-andrea-bocelli-perfect-chart-beat-podcast |access-date=26 September 2018 |magazine=Billboard |archive-date=21 October 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211021215353/https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/podcasts/8097573/matt-sheeran-ed-sheeran-andrea-bocelli-perfect-chart-beat-podcast |url-status=live }}</ref> Sheeran's parents, John and Imogen, are from London. His father is Irish,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wjlondon.com/athurs-day-ed-sheeran-interview/|title=Arthur's Day: Ed Sheeran interview -|date=21 September 2011|access-date=7 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170802044151/http://wjlondon.com/athurs-day-ed-sheeran-interview/|archive-date=2 August 2017|url-status=dead}}</ref>{{sfn|Nolan|2012|pp=1\u20136}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/music/ed-sheeran-irish-blood-english-heart-26779193.html|title=Ed Sheeran: Irish blood, English heart|last=Welch|first=Andy|date=10 June 2011|website=[[Irish Independent]]|access-date=8 November 2015|archive-date=15 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615032300/https://www.independent.ie/entertainment/music/ed-sheeran-irish-blood-english-heart-26779193.html|url-status=live}}</ref> and Sheeran has stated that his father is from a \"very large\" [[Irish Catholic|Catholic]] family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://965tic.cbslocal.com/2013/08/06/qa-with-ed-sheeran-at-the-acoustic-cafe/|title=Q&A With Ed Sheeran at the Acoustic Caf\u00e9|last=Roman|first=Tyler|date=6 August 2013|website=Cbslocal.com|access-date=8 November 2015|archive-date=19 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119083438/http://965tic.cbslocal.com/2013/08/06/qa-with-ed-sheeran-at-the-acoustic-cafe/|url-status=live}}</ref> John is an art curator and lecturer, and Imogen is a culture publicist turned jewellery designer.{{sfn|Nolan|2012|pp=1\u20136}}<ref>{{cite news|last=Sage|first=Sarky|date=31 March 2011|title=Framlingham: Pop star Ed Sheeran's mum has success with jewellery range \u2013 News \u2013 East Anglian Daily Times|url=http://www.eadt.co.uk/news/framlingham_pop_star_ed_sheeran_s_mum_has_success_with_jewellery_range_1_844578|newspaper=[[East Anglian Daily Times]]|access-date=8 November 2015|archive-date=3 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303175505/http://www.eadt.co.uk/news/framlingham_pop_star_ed_sheeran_s_mum_has_success_with_jewellery_range_1_844578|url-status=live}}</ref> His parents ran Sheeran Lock, an independent art consultancy, from 1990 to 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.suffolkmag.co.uk/people/celebrity-interviews/the_man_who_loves_art_1_3608139|title=The man who loves art|last=Larner|first=Catherine|date=20 May 2014|publisher=Suffolkmag.co.uk|access-date=9 November 2015|archive-date=17 March 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170317074414/http://www.suffolkmag.co.uk/people/celebrity-interviews/the_man_who_loves_art_1_3608139|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nSheeran sang at a local church choir at the age of four, learned how to play the guitar at age eleven,<ref name=\"Clapton\"/> and began writing songs while at Thomas Mills High School in Framlingham.<ref name=\"auto\"/><ref name=\"intro\"/> He also played the cello when he was younger.<ref name=\"ClassicFM-2022-01-23\">{{cite web |last=Alexandra |first=Sophia |url=https://www.classicfm.com/music-news/ed-sheeran-yo-yo-ma/ |title=Ed Sheeran: 'Yo-Yo Ma emailed me to tell me he loved my song Shape of You' |publisher=[[Classic FM (UK)|Classic FM]] |place=London |date=23 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220123084549/https://www.classicfm.com/music-news/ed-sheeran-yo-yo-ma/ |accessdate=26 August 2022 |archive-date=23 January 2022 |url-status=live }}</ref> A 2004 school report described him as a \"natural performer\", and his classmates also voted him \"most likely to be famous\".<ref name=\"Exhibition\">{{cite news |title=Ed Sheeran exhibition in Ipswich features college drop-out letter |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-suffolk-49398768 |date=19 August 2019 |work=[[BBC News]] |access-date=19 August 2019 |archive-date=12 December 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211212010225/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-suffolk-49398768 |url-status=live }}</ref> He was accepted at the [[National Youth Theatre]] in London as a teenager.<ref>{{cite web |first=Richard |last=Haugh |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/suffolk/content/articles/2008/04/22/introducing_ed_sheeran_feature.shtml |title=Suffolk \u2013 Entertainment \u2013 Ed Sheeran |publisher=BBC |date=22 April 2008 |access-date=8 June 2013 |archive-date=11 January 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180111084619/http://www.bbc.co.uk/suffolk/content/articles/2008/04/22/introducing_ed_sheeran_feature.shtml |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scoutlondon.com/2013/02/01/ed-sheeran-i-want-a-couple-of-months-off/ |title=Ed Sheeran: 'I want a couple of months off' &#124; Scout London > Music |publisher=Scout London |date=1 February 2013 |access-date=8 June 2013 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140225022922/http://www.scoutlondon.com/2013/02/01/ed-sheeran-i-want-a-couple-of-months-off/ |archive-date=25 February 2014 }}</ref> He successfully auditioned for [[Youth Music Theatre UK]] in 2007 and joined their production of ''[[Frankenstein \u2013 A New Musical]]'' in [[Plymouth]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://britishyouthmusictheatre.org/shows/frankenstein-2007 |title=Frankenstein (2007). Barbican Theatre, Plymouth, Cast |website=[[British Youth Music Theatre]] |access-date=20 December 2018 |archive-date=21 October 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211021215029/https://britishyouthmusictheatre.org/shows/frankenstein-2007 |url-status=live }}</ref> He is a patron of Youth Music Theatre UK (now renamed British Youth Music Theatre)<ref name=\"Patron\">{{cite web|date=28 January 2013 |title=Sheeran penned 26 new album tracks |url=http://music.uk.msn.com/news/sheeran-penned-26-new-album-tracks|work=MSN Music |publisher=[[MSN]] |access-date=12 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130130160724/http://music.uk.msn.com/news/sheeran-penned-26-new-album-tracks|archive-date=30 January 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref> and of [[Access to Music]], where he studied Artist Development.<ref>{{cite web|title=Patron Ed Sheeran|url=http://www.accesstomusic.co.uk/patron_ed-sheeran-7|website=Access to Music|access-date=12 August 2015|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151003105903/http://www.accesstomusic.co.uk/patron_ed-sheeran-7|archive-date=3 October 2015}}</ref><ref name=\"Access to Music\">{{cite web|title=Student Success Stories|url=http://www.accesstomusic.co.uk/success-stories|website=Access to Music|access-date=12 August 2015|archive-date=1 September 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170901233818/http://www.accesstomusic.co.uk/success-stories|url-status=live}}</ref> Sheeran is a [[second cousin]] of Northern Irish broadcaster [[Gordon Burns]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/film-and-tv/gordon-burns-so-proud-over-682724 |title=Gordon Burns 'so proud' over cousin Ed Sheeran's Brit Awards success |work=Manchester Evening News |date=23 February 2012 |access-date=7 June 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141028040821/http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/film-and-tv/gordon-burns-so-proud-over-682724 |archive-date=28 October 2014 }}</ref> who hosted the British game show ''[[The Krypton Factor]]''.{{sfn|Nolan|2012|pp=1\u20136}}\n\n==Career==\n===2004\u20132010: Career beginnings===\n[[File:12 - Ed Sheeran.jpg|thumb|right|160px|Sheeran performing at the Ipswich Arts Festival in July 2010]]\n\nSheeran began recording music in 2004, and at the age of thirteen independently released his first collection of work, titled ''Spinning Man''.{{efn|group=upper-alpha|\"In 2004, I made my very first album, ''Spinning Man'', named after a picture that my dad had. I burnt the CDs myself and made the covers. There were 14 songs and they were all songs that rhymed. One lyric went: '''I'm a typical average teen, if you know what I mean.''' There are probably 20 copies of ''Spinning Man'' in existence and I have 19 of them. I don't want anyone else to get hold of a copy. Most of the songs were about a girl named Claire. She was my first love when I was 13. It was a very innocent love and we only ever held hands, but it lasted a fair amount of time. Then came my first devastating break-up. Looking back, it really wasn't that bad, but at the time it was soul-shattering. When she left me, I wrote a lot of songs off the back of it\u2014my first love songs.\"<ref>''Ed Sheeran: A Visual Journey'', p.&nbsp;38</ref>}} He has been friends with fellow English singer [[Passenger (singer)|Passenger]] since he was 15, with the two playing the same gig in Cambridge.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/music/2012/12/07/passenger_aka_mike_rosenberg_grateful_for_ed_sheerans_support.html|title=Passenger, a.k.a. Mike Rosenberg, grateful for Ed Sheeran's support|work=Toronto Star|date=7 December 2012|access-date=28 September 2014|archive-date=5 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190905175122/https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/music/2012/12/07/passenger_aka_mike_rosenberg_grateful_for_ed_sheerans_support.html|url-status=live}}</ref> He moved to London in 2008 and began playing in small venues. In 2008, he auditioned for the ITV series ''[[Britannia High]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scotsman.com/edinburgh-evening-news/edinburgh/interview-ed-sheeran-musician-1-2039807|title=Interview: Ed Sheeran, musician|date=5 January 2012|work=Edinburgh Evening News|access-date=23 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407085515/http://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/what-s-on/music/interview-ed-sheeran-musician-1-2039807|archive-date=7 April 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref> He also opened for [[Nizlopi]] in Norwich in April 2008, after being one of their guitar technicians.<ref name=\"intro\"/> In the autumn of 2009, Sheeran began studying music at the [[Academy of Contemporary Music]] (ACM) in [[Guildford]], Surrey as an undergraduate at the age of 18,<ref name=acm1>{{cite web|url=http://www.acm.ac.uk/ed-sheeran-musician-and-songwriter/|title=Featured Alumni: Ed Sheeran \u2013 Musician/Songwriter|date=6 October 2015|access-date=8 November 2016|archive-date=29 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170729224303/https://www.acm.ac.uk/ed-sheeran-musician-and-songwriter/|url-status=live}}</ref> but left without permission in the same year to support hip-hop artist [[Just Jack]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/ed-sheeran-donates-200k-boosts-22900266|title=Ed Sheeran donates \u00a3200k and boosts results at old school where he met wife Cherry|date=24 October 2020|work=Mirror|access-date=13 November 2012|archive-date=16 August 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220816094521/https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/ed-sheeran-donates-200k-boosts-22900266|url-status=live}}</ref>\nHe released another EP in 2009, ''You Need Me'', and also collaborated several times with Essex singer [[Leddra Chapman]], including [[CeeLo Green]]'s \"[[Fuck You (CeeLo Green song)|Fuck You]]\". In February 2010, Sheeran posted a video through [[SB.TV]]\u2014a channel launched by British entrepreneur [[Jamal Edwards]]\u2014and rapper [[Example (musician)|Example]] invited Sheeran to tour with him.<ref>{{cite news |title=Jamal Edwards, music entrepreneur and YouTube star, dies aged 31 |url=https://news.sky.com/story/jamal-edwards-music-entrepreneur-and-youtube-star-dies-aged-31-12547675 |access-date=21 February 2022 |work=[[Sky News]] |archive-date=20 February 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220220234057/https://news.sky.com/story/jamal-edwards-music-entrepreneur-and-youtube-star-dies-aged-31-12547675 |url-status=live }}</ref> In the same month, he also released his critically acclaimed ''[[Loose Change (EP)|Loose Change]]'' EP, which featured his future debut single, \"[[The A Team (Ed Sheeran song)|The A Team]]\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://soulsidefunk.com/2010/03/12/interview-with-ed-sheeran/ |title=Interview with Ed Sheeran |date=12 March 2010 |website=Soulside funk |access-date=30 November 2014 |archive-date=29 June 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180629102811/https://soulsidefunk.com/2010/03/12/interview-with-ed-sheeran/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nSheeran began to be seen by more people over the internet through YouTube and his fan base expanded, with him also receiving praise from ''[[The Independent]]'' newspaper and [[Elton John]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Singer Ed Sheeran: 'Elton John is a fan of my music' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/entertainment-arts-14718488/singer-ed-sheeran-elton-john-is-a-fan-of-my-music |work=[[BBC News]] |date=3 January 2019 |access-date=27 August 2022 |archive-date=23 May 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200523234601/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/entertainment-arts-14718488/singer-ed-sheeran-elton-john-is-a-fan-of-my-music |url-status=live }}</ref> He played a ''Station Session'' in [[St Pancras railway station|St. Pancras International]] in June 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DKEkAf4EYCA|title=The Station Sessions: Ed Sheeran (10 June 2010)|date=6 May 2017 |access-date=3 August 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170816212256/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DKEkAf4EYCA|archive-date=16 August 2017|url-status=live|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/radio/q/blog/watch-ed-sheeran-play-in-a-london-train-station-before-he-was-famous-1.4200070 | title=Watch Ed Sheeran play in a London train station before he was famous \u2013 Blog | work=[[Q (radio show)|q]] | publisher=[[CBC Radio]] | access-date=13 September 2017 | author=Van Evra, Jennifer | archive-date=15 August 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170815134842/http://www.cbc.ca/radio/q/blog/watch-ed-sheeran-play-in-a-london-train-station-before-he-was-famous-1.4200070 | url-status=live }}</ref> Some of the episode is on their Facebook page<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/StationSessions/videos/103760926340944/|title=Ed Sheeran \u2013 The Station Sessions \u2013 10th June 2010|via=facebook.com|access-date=27 August 2022|archive-date=8 April 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220408153746/https://www.facebook.com/StationSessions/videos/103760926340944/|url-status=live}}</ref> Sheeran also self-released two other EPs in 2010, ''Ed Sheeran: Live at the Bedford'' and ''[[Songs I Wrote with Amy]]'', which is a collection of love songs he wrote in Wales with [[Amy Wadge]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/whats-on/arts-culture-news/ed-sheeran-thinking-out-loud-7345585|title=How I wrote Ed Sheeran's song... on Harry Styles' guitar|last=Price|first=Karen|date=30 June 2014|work=walesonline|access-date=17 October 2018|archive-date=27 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180827174126/https://www.walesonline.co.uk/whats-on/arts-culture-news/ed-sheeran-thinking-out-loud-7345585|url-status=live}}</ref> When in Los Angeles in 2010, he was invited to perform at The Foxxhole, a club run by actor [[Jamie Foxx]], which ended with an invitation to stay at Foxx's home.<ref name=\"Telegraph 2017\">{{cite news|title=Ed Sheeran: 'I haven't got used to the screams'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopfeatures/8679492/Ed-Sheeran-I-havent-got-used-to-the-screams.html|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=12 December 2017|access-date=27 August 2022|archive-date=17 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180617211441/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopfeatures/8679492/Ed-Sheeran-I-havent-got-used-to-the-screams.html|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nOn 8 January 2011, Sheeran released another independent EP, ''[[No. 5 Collaborations Project]]'', featuring grime artists such as [[Wiley (rapper)|Wiley]], [[Jme (MC)|Jme]], [[Devlin (rapper)|Devlin]], [[Sway (British musician)|Sway]] and [[Ghetts]].<ref name=bbcsuffolk>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/suffolk/hi/people_and_places/music/newsid_9354000/9354954.stm|work=BBC News|access-date=10 August 2011|date=10 January 2011|title=Ed Sheeran battles Rihanna for top spot in album chart|first=Richard|last=Haugh|archive-date=14 January 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110114061930/http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/suffolk/hi/people_and_places/music/newsid_9354000/9354954.stm|url-status=live}}</ref> With this EP, Sheeran gained mainstream attention for having reached number 2 in the [[iTunes]] chart without any promotion or label, selling over 7,000 copies in the first week.<ref name=signing>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/suffolk/hi/people_and_places/music/newsid_9354000/9354954.stm |title=Ed Sheeran signs with Asylum Records / Atlantic Records following 'No. 5 Collaborations Project' success |work=BBC News |date=13 January 2011 |access-date=19 January 2011 |archive-date=14 January 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110114061930/http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/suffolk/hi/people_and_places/music/newsid_9354000/9354954.stm |url-status=live }}</ref> Three months later, Sheeran put on a free show to fans at the Barfly in [[Camden Town]]. Over 1,000 fans turned up, so Sheeran played four different shows to ensure everyone saw a gig, including a gig outside on the street after the venue had closed. Later that month, Sheeran was signed to [[Asylum Records]].<ref name=signing/>\n\n===2011\u20132013: ''+'' (\"''Plus''\")===\nOn 26 April 2011, Sheeran appeared on the BBC music show ''[[Later... with Jools Holland]]'', where he performed his debut single \"The A Team\". Six weeks later, \"The A Team\" was released as a digital download in the UK. The release served as the lead single from Sheeran's debut studio album, ''[[+ (album)|+]]'' (\"Plus\").<ref>{{cite news|last=Lipshutz|first=Jason|title=Ed Sheeran, 'x': Track-By-Track Review|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/review/6128781/ed-sheeran-x-track-by-track-album-review|issue=24 November 2015|magazine=Billboard|date=23 June 2014|access-date=27 August 2022|archive-date=16 May 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210516000257/https://www.billboard.com/articles/review/6128781/ed-sheeran-x-track-by-track-album-review|url-status=live}}</ref> \"The A Team\" entered the [[UK Singles Chart]] at number three, selling over 58,000 copies in the first week. It was the best-selling debut single and the overall eighth-best selling single of 2011, selling 801,000 copies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/the-top-20-biggest-selling-singles-of-2011-revealed/ |title=The Top 20 biggest selling singles of 2011 revealed! |publisher=Officialcharts.com |access-date=8 June 2013 |archive-date=20 June 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160620014158/http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/the-top-20-biggest-selling-singles-of-2011-revealed/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The lead single also became a top ten hit in Australia, Germany, Ireland, Japan, Luxembourg, New Zealand, Norway and the Netherlands. During a headline set in the [[BBC Introducing]] tent at [[Glastonbury Festival 2011]], Sheeran announced that \"[[You Need Me, I Don't Need You]]\" would be released on 26 August as the second single from the album. The second single peaked at number four on the UK Singles Chart.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.officialcharts.com/charts/singles-chart/20110904/7501/ |title=2011-09-10 Top 40 Official UK Singles Archive |publisher=[[Official Charts Company]] |date=10 September 2011 |access-date=8 June 2013 |archive-date=24 June 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150624032544/http://www.officialcharts.com/charts/singles-chart/20110904/7501/ |url-status=live }}</ref> \"[[Lego House]]\" was released as the third single, reaching the top ten on the Australian, Irish and New Zealand Singles Charts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/album/lego-house-ep/id474197789|title=Lego House \u2013 EP by Ed Sheeran on Apple Music|date=11 November 2011|publisher=iTunes Store|access-date=27 August 2022|archive-date=5 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305075953/https://itunes.apple.com/gb/album/lego-house-ep/id474197789|url-status=live}}</ref> The music video for \"Lego House\" features actor [[Rupert Grint]], as a play on their similar appearance.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=5 times Rupert Grint and Ed Sheeran joked about being the same person |url=https://ew.com/music/2017/03/22/rupert-grint-ed-sheeran-moments/ |magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=8 May 2018 |access-date=27 August 2022 |archive-date=8 April 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220408153746/https://ew.com/music/2017/03/22/rupert-grint-ed-sheeran-moments/ |url-status=live }}</ref> \"[[Drunk (Ed Sheeran song)|Drunk]]\", released on 19 February 2012, became Sheeran's fourth consecutive top-ten single in the UK, peaking at number nine.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.officialcharts.com/charts/singles-chart/20120304/7501/ |title=2012-03-10 Top 40 Official UK Singles Archive |publisher=[[Official Charts Company]] |date=10 March 2012 |access-date=8 June 2013 |archive-date=26 May 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150526213417/http://www.officialcharts.com/charts/singles-chart/20120304/7501 |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n[[File:Ed Sheeran at 2012 Frequency Festival in Austria (7852625324).jpg|thumb|left|Sheeran at the [[FM4 Frequency Festival|Frequency Festival]] in Austria, August 2012]]\nSheeran released ''+'' on 12 September 2011. The album received generally favourable reviews from music critics<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.metacritic.com/music/+/critic-reviews |title=Critic Reviews for + |website=Metacritic |access-date=8 June 2013 |archive-date=24 July 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130724072157/http://www.metacritic.com/music/+/critic-reviews |url-status=live }}</ref> and debuted at number one on the [[UK Albums Chart]] for sales of 102,000 copies.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a340995/ed-sheeran-tops-uk-album-chart-with-.html|title=Ed Sheeran tops UK album chart with '+'|last=Sperling|first=Daniel|date=18 September 2011|work=Digital Spy|access-date=23 May 2012|archive-date=27 January 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120127024410/http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a340995/ed-sheeran-tops-uk-album-chart-with-.html|url-status=live}}</ref> By end of 2011, sales of the album in the UK stood at 791,000; it became the second-best-selling debut album and the ninth-biggest-selling album there.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/the-top-20-biggest-selling-albums-of-2011-revealed/ |title=The Top 20 biggest selling albums of 2011 revealed! |publisher=Officialcharts.com |access-date=8 June 2013 |archive-date=28 June 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120628051320/http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/the-top-20-biggest-selling-albums-of-2011-revealed/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The album has been certified platinum six times by the [[British Phonographic Industry]], denoting shipments of 1.8 million copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bpi.co.uk/certified-awards.aspx |title=BPI Search Page by Artist |publisher=BPI |access-date=28 September 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140625075145/http://www.bpi.co.uk/certified-awards.aspx |archive-date=25 June 2014 }}</ref> As of March 2012, the album had sold 1,021,072 copies in the UK.<ref>{{cite web|first=Alan|last=Jones|title=Official Chart Analysis: Sande thrives in Scotland, Ed Sheeran album tops 1m sales in UK|url=http://www.musicweek.com/story.asp?sectioncode=1&storycode=1048723&c=1|work=[[Music Week]]|access-date=6 March 2012|date=5 March 2012|archive-date=24 July 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130724074247/http://www.musicweek.com/story.asp?sectioncode=1&storycode=1048723&c=1|url-status=live}}</ref> The album also reached the top five in Australia, Canada, Ireland, New Zealand and the US.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ed Sheeran Album & Song Chart History: Billboard 200|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/276089/ed+sheeran/chart?f=305|magazine=Billboard|date=15 November 2015|access-date=27 August 2022|archive-date=9 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150709065655/http://www.billboard.com/artist/276089/ed+sheeran/chart?f=305|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chart-track.co.uk/index.jsp?c=p%2Fmusicvideo%2Fmusic%2Farchive%2Findex_test.jsp&ct=240002&arch=t&lyr=2011&year=2011&week=37 |title=GFK Chart-Track |publisher=Chart-track.co.uk |access-date=3 March 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130724070739/http://www.chart-track.co.uk/index.jsp?c=p%2Fmusicvideo%2Fmusic%2Farchive%2Findex_test.jsp&ct=240002&arch=t&lyr=2011&year=2011&week=37 |archive-date=24 July 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://charts.nz/showitem.asp?interpret=Ed+Sheeran&titel=%2B&cat=a|title=charts.nz \u2013 Ed Sheeran \u2013 +|publisher=Hung Medien|access-date=7 March 2012|archive-date=5 April 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170405220219/http://charts.nz/showitem.asp?interpret=Ed+Sheeran&titel=%2B&cat=a|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nThe song, \"[[Moments (One Direction song)|Moments]]\", on the [[Up All Night (One Direction album)|debut album]] by boy band [[One Direction]], released in November 2011, was co-written by Sheeran.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a345784/one-direction-name-debut-album-up-all-night-reveal-cover.html|title=One Direction name debut album|work=[[Digital Spy]]|date=2 November 2012|access-date=27 August 2022|archive-date=8 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108063846/http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a345784/one-direction-name-debut-album-up-all-night-reveal-cover.html|url-status=live}}</ref> At the [[2012 Brit Awards]] on 21 February, Sheeran won the Brit Awards for [[Brit Award for British Male Solo Artist|Best British Male Solo Artist]], and [[Brit Award for British Breakthrough Act|British Breakthrough Act]] of the Year.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-16533246|title=Brit Awards 2012: List of winners|work=[[BBC News]]|date=21 February 2012|access-date=28 September 2014|archive-date=6 August 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170806234343/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-16533246|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/adele-coldplay-lead-brit-award-nominations-20120112 |title=Adele, Coldplay Lead BRIT Award Nominations |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=12 January 2012 |access-date=28 September 2014 |archive-date=1 July 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140701085144/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/adele-coldplay-lead-brit-award-nominations-20120112 |url-status=live }}</ref> On 10 January 2012, it was announced that Sheeran would support [[Snow Patrol]] on their US tour from late March until May.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sinchronicitymagazine.com/2012/01/ed-sheeran-announces-us-tour/ |title=Ed Sheeran Announces US Supporting Tour |publisher=Sinchronicity |date=11 January 2012 |access-date=15 January 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://archive.today/20120717183352/http://sinchronicitymagazine.com/2012/01/ed-sheeran-announces-us-tour/ |archive-date=17 July 2012 }}</ref> His song, \"[[Give Me Love (Ed Sheeran song)|Give Me Love]]\", was featured in the episode \"[[The Birthday (The Vampire Diaries)|Dangerous Liaisons]]\" of ''[[The Vampire Diaries]]''.<ref>{{cite web |title='The Vampire Diaries' recap: In which Elena is starting to get on our nerves |url=http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2012/02/the-vampire-diaries-recap-are-you-suggesting-i-cant-be-gentle.html |work=[[Zap2it]] |access-date=16 February 2012 |first=Carina Adly |last=MacKenzie |date=10 February 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120215072514/http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2012/02/the-vampire-diaries-recap-are-you-suggesting-i-cant-be-gentle.html |archive-date=15 February 2012 }}</ref> At the [[Ivor Novello Awards]] in May 2012, Sheeran's \"The A Team\" bested [[Adele]]'s \"[[Rolling in the Deep]]\" and [[Florence and the Machine]]'s \"[[Shake It Out]]\" for Best Song Musically and Lyrically.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-18107224 |title=Adele wins Ivor Novello Awards double |work=[[BBC News]] |date=17 May 2012 |access-date=17 May 2012 |archive-date=17 May 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120517174346/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-18107224 |url-status=live }}</ref> Sheeran performed \"The A Team\" at the [[Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II|Diamond Jubilee of Queen Elizabeth II]] [[Diamond Jubilee Concert|concert]] held on [[The Mall, London|The Mall]] outside [[Buckingham Palace]] on 4 June 2012 and a cover of [[Pink Floyd]]'s \"[[Wish You Were Here (Pink Floyd song)|Wish You Were Here]]\" at the [[2012 Summer Olympics closing ceremony|closing ceremony]] of the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in London on 12 August 2012.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ed Sheeran Olympics Closing Ceremony: Singer Wears Hoodie, Sings Pink Floyd |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/12/ed-sheeran-olympics-closi_n_1771077.html |work=HuffPost |access-date=13 August 2012 |first=Carolyn |last=Gregoire |date=12 August 2012 |archive-date=14 August 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120814051327/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/12/ed-sheeran-olympics-closi_n_1771077.html |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n[[Taylor Swift]] contacted Sheeran after hearing his music while touring Australia in March 2012.<ref name=\"billboard.com\">{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1496478/ed-sheeran-to-record-new-album-on-taylor-swift-tour |title=Ed Sheeran to Record New Album on Taylor Swift Tour |magazine=Billboard |date=16 January 2013 |access-date=8 June 2013 |archive-date=30 May 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130530180835/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1496478/ed-sheeran-to-record-new-album-on-taylor-swift-tour |url-status=live }}</ref> He later co-wrote and provided vocals for \"[[Everything Has Changed]]\", a single featured on Swift's fourth studio album, ''[[Red (Taylor Swift album)|Red]]''. Sheeran also contributed two songs to One Direction's second studio album, ''[[Take Me Home (One Direction album)|Take Me Home]]'', released in November 2012; the single \"[[Little Things (One Direction song)|Little Things]]\" became the group's second number-one in the UK.<ref>{{cite news |first=Dan |last=Lane |url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/one-direction-score-number-1-single-and-album-1719/ |title=One Direction score Number 1 single AND album! |publisher=[[Official Charts Company]] |date=18 November 2012 |access-date=19 November 2012 |location=United Kingdom |archive-date=30 August 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180830142315/http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/one-direction-score-number-1-single-and-album-__2564/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Sheeran's album peaked at No. 5 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], while \"The A Team\" reached No. 16 on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].<ref name=\"billboard.com\"/> In late 2012 and early 2013, he headlined a US tour of 6,000\u20139,000-capacity venues.<ref name=\"billboard.com\"/> \"The A Team\" received a nomination for Song of the Year at the [[55th Annual Grammy Awards|2013 Grammy Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/news/grammy-awards/370372-grammy-awards-2013-nominations-frank-ocean-fun|title=2013 Grammy Nominations|date=6 December 2012|publisher=MTV|access-date=6 December 2012|archive-date=20 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151120084047/http://www.mtv.co.uk/grammy-awards/news/frank-ocean-fun-lead-2013-grammy-award-nominations|url-status=dead}}</ref> [[Elton John]], who runs Sheeran's management company, canvassed the award organisers to get Sheeran a performance slot at the ceremony but was told that Sheeran alone was not high-profile enough. John decided to appear with Sheeran to circumvent this problem.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cMM5zMsq2a8 |title=Ed Sheeran on the Grammys |via=YouTube |date=7 February 2013 |access-date=8 June 2013 |archive-date=10 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130210063050/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cMM5zMsq2a8 |url-status=live }}</ref> Sheeran was also featured on some tracks from Irish singer [[Foy Vance]]'s fourth album ''[[Joy of Nothing]]''.<ref>{{cite web | author=folkradiouk | title=Foy Vance new album: Joy of Nothing (+ documentary) | website=Folk Radio UK \u2013 Folk Music Magazine | date=10 June 2013 | url=http://www.folkradio.co.uk/2013/06/foy-vance-debut-album-joy-of-nothing-documentary/ | access-date=6 September 2018 | archive-date=15 June 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615024450/http://www.folkradio.co.uk/2013/06/foy-vance-debut-album-joy-of-nothing-documentary/ | url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nFrom March to September 2013, Sheeran played at arenas and stadiums across North America as the opening act for Swift's [[The Red Tour]].<ref>{{cite news|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|date=27 October 2012|title=Taylor Swift Tour to Paint the Road 'Red'|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/474440/taylor-swift-tour-to-paint-the-road-red|magazine=Billboard|access-date=6 December 2012|archive-date=12 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130212163215/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/474440/taylor-swift-tour-to-paint-the-road-red|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=\"Telegraph-McLean\">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/10859780/Ed-Sheeran-interview-I-dont-make-music-for-critics.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220110/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/10859780/Ed-Sheeran-interview-I-dont-make-music-for-critics.html |archive-date=10 January 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live|title=Ed Sheeran interview: 'I don't make music for critics'|last=McLean|first=Craig|date=16 July 2014|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|access-date=14 November 2015}}{{cbignore}}</ref> According to Sheeran, it was then his biggest tour, and he added a scarlet RED tattoo to commemorate it.<ref name=\"MTV-Kaufman\">{{cite web|last=Kaufman|first=Gil|date=31 October 2012|title=Ed Sheeran Calls Taylor Swift Opening Gig 'Mind-blowing' \u2013 Music, Celebrity, Artist News|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1696524/taylor-swift-ed-sheeran-opening-act-red-tour.jhtml|publisher=MTV News|access-date=8 June 2013|archive-date=19 April 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130419010412/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1696524/taylor-swift-ed-sheeran-opening-act-red-tour.jhtml|url-status=dead}}</ref> In October 2013, Sheeran headlined three sold-out shows at New York's [[Madison Square Garden]].<ref name=\"Telegraph-McLean\"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Garibaldi|first=Christina|date=2 November 2013|title=Taylor Swift Gives Ed Sheeran Some 'Love' With Surprise Concert Appearance|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1716719/ed-sheeran-taylor-swift-concert-surprise-new-york-city/|publisher=MTV News|access-date=14 November 2015|archive-date=9 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141209074324/http://www.mtv.com/news/1716719/ed-sheeran-taylor-swift-concert-surprise-new-york-city/|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/tv/videos/watch-ed-sheeran-perform-sweet-thinking-out-loud-for-austin-city-limits-20150403|title=Watch Ed Sheeran Perform Sweet 'Thinking Out Loud' for 'Austin City Limits'|last=Spanos|first=Brittany|author-link=Brittany Spanos|date=3 April 2015|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=14 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151127054936/https://www.rollingstone.com/tv/videos/watch-ed-sheeran-perform-sweet-thinking-out-loud-for-austin-city-limits-20150403|archive-date=27 November 2015|url-status=live}}</ref> At the concert, Sheeran debuted new songs, including \"[[Tenerife Sea]]\",<ref>{{cite news|last=Kaufman|first=Gil|date=20 March 2014|title=If Ed Sheeran Sees His Own Shadow, Will He Drop A New Single in April?|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1724462/if-ed-sheeran-sees-his-own-shadow-will-he-drop-a-new-single-in-april/|publisher=MTV News|access-date=14 November 2015|archive-date=17 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117192133/http://www.mtv.com/news/1724462/if-ed-sheeran-sees-his-own-shadow-will-he-drop-a-new-single-in-april/|url-status=dead}}</ref> a future track on his second studio album. Sheeran released \"[[I See Fire]]\" on 5 November 2013. The song is featured in the [[closing credits|end credits]] of the film ''[[The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug]]'', [[Music of The Hobbit series|the film's soundtrack]], and on the deluxe version of his second album.<ref>{{cite news|last=Harris|first=Jamie|date=5 November 2013|title=Ed Sheeran debuts new solo song 'I See Fire' for 'Hobbit' movie|url=http://www.digitalspy.com.au/music/news/a528784/ed-sheeran-debuts-new-solo-song-i-see-fire-for-hobbit-movie-listen.html|work=Digital Spy|location=Australia|access-date=19 February 2014|archive-date=24 February 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140224025856/http://www.digitalspy.com.au/music/news/a528784/ed-sheeran-debuts-new-solo-song-i-see-fire-for-hobbit-movie-listen.html|url-status=live}}</ref> Sheeran was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]] at the [[56th Annual Grammy Awards|2014 Grammy Awards]].<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5819883/grammy-awards-2014-full-nominations-list-complete-nominees |title=Grammy Awards 2014: Full Nominations List |magazine=Billboard |date=6 December 2013 |access-date=29 March 2014 |archive-date=13 August 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160813121343/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5819883/grammy-awards-2014-full-nominations-list-complete-nominees |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n===2014\u20132015: ''\u00d7'' (\"''Multiply''\")===\n\nOn 24 March 2014, Sheeran performed at the [[Teenage Cancer Trust]] charity concert at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in London where he unveiled \"Take It Back\", a track that would appear on the deluxe version of the second album.<ref>{{cite news|last=Talbot|first=Martin|date=25 March 2014|title=British singer/songwriters get Teenage Cancer Trust benefit shows off to a storming start at London's Royal Albert Hall|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/ed-sheeran-and-passenger-unveil-new-songs-at-teenage-cancer-trust-show__3893/|publisher=Official Charts Company|access-date=14 November 2015|archive-date=17 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117103613/http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/ed-sheeran-and-passenger-unveil-new-songs-at-teenage-cancer-trust-show__3893/|url-status=live}}</ref> \"[[Sing (Ed Sheeran song)|Sing]]\", the lead single, was released on 7 April 2014. Sonically, the song is a departure from Sheeran's previous recordings.<ref name=\"BB-Lipshutz\">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/6041312/ed-sheeran-billboard-cover-story|title=Ed Sheeran Un-Zipped: On His Pharrell-Produced Single, Being a Sex Symbol and Turning Betrayal Into Song (Cover Story)|last=Lipshutz|first=Jason|date=7 April 2014|magazine=Billboard|access-date=14 November 2015|archive-date=20 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151120073226/http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/6041312/ed-sheeran-billboard-cover-story|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://time.com/52180/ed-sheeran-sing-pharrell/|title=Ed Sheeran Teams Up With Pharrell for New Single \"Sing\": Listen|last=St. Asaph|first=Katherine|date=7 April 2014|magazine=Time|access-date=14 November 2015|archive-date=6 August 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200806015632/https://time.com/52180/ed-sheeran-sing-pharrell/|url-status=live}}</ref> \"Sing\" was intended to create hype over the album release, but from concern that this might alienate Sheeran's fan base, \"[[One (Ed Sheeran song)|One]]\", an acoustic ballad, was released on 16 May 2014;<ref name=\"Telegraph-McLean\"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/entertainment/music/2014/08/23/interview-ed-sheeran-x-pharrell-elton-john/14403209/|title=Interview: Ed Sheeran on 'X,' Pharrell and Elton John|last=Masley|first=Ed|date=27 August 2014|work=[[The Arizona Republic]]|access-date=14 November 2015|archive-date=16 August 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220816094521/https://www.azcentral.com/story/entertainment/music/2014/08/23/interview-ed-sheeran-x-pharrell-elton-john/14403209/|url-status=live}}</ref> \"One\" also marked the first of several promotional singles released leading to the album release. By early June 2014, \"Sing\" had earned Sheeran his first number-one single in the UK.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lane|first=Dan|date=8 June 2014|title=Ed Sheeran scores first ever Number 1 single with Sing|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/ed-sheeran-scores-first-ever-number-1-single-with-sing__4192/|publisher=Official Charts Company|access-date=15 November 2015|archive-date=16 August 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220816094524/https://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/ed-sheeran-scores-first-ever-number-1-single-with-sing__4192/|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nSheeran's second studio album, ''[[x (Ed Sheeran album)|\u00d7]]'' (\"Multiply\"), was released worldwide on 23 June 2014. Spanning three years, Sheeran wrote more than 120 songs for the album.<ref name=\"RS-Doyle\">{{cite news|last=Doyle|first=Patrick|date=7 April 2014|title=Ed Sheeran's Heartache and Wildest Nights: Behind His Raw LP 'X'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/ed-sheerans-heartache-and-wildest-nights-behind-his-raw-lp-x-20140407|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=14 November 2015|archive-date=4 September 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170904063115/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/ed-sheerans-heartache-and-wildest-nights-behind-his-raw-lp-x-20140407|url-status=live}}</ref> The album features tracks produced by [[Rick Rubin]], [[Pharrell Williams]] and [[Benny Blanco]],<ref name=\"RS-Doyle\"/> as well as that of Gosling's.<ref name=\"BB-Lipshutz\"/> ''\u00d7'' peaked at number one in both the UK Albums Chart and the US ''Billboard'' 200. To support the album, Sheeran embarked on [[x Tour (Ed Sheeran tour)|a world tour]] starting on 6 August 2014 at [[Osaka]], Japan. On 27 September 2014, Sheeran was one of the headline acts at the [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] prior to the [[2014 AFL Grand Final]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Cashmere|first=Paul|date=28 September 2014|title=Baron Ed Sheeran Performs With Sir Tom Jones at AFL Grand Final|url=http://www.noise11.com/news/baron-ed-sheeran-performs-with-sir-tom-jones-at-afl-grand-final-20140928|publisher=Noise11|access-date=15 November 2015|archive-date=17 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117015417/http://www.noise11.com/news/baron-ed-sheeran-performs-with-sir-tom-jones-at-afl-grand-final-20140928|url-status=live}}</ref>\nFollowing \"[[Don't (Ed Sheeran song)|Don't]]\", \"[[Thinking Out Loud]]\" was released on 24 September 2014 as the album's third single. Unlike his previous music videos, Sheeran took the lead role in the single's accompaniment, where he performed a ballroom dance.<ref>{{cite news|last=Parker|first=Lyndsey|date=9 October 2014|title=Sheeran Busts Out the Ballroom Moves in 'Thinking Out Loud' Video|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/sheeran-busts-out-the-ballroom-moves-in-thinking-out-loud-video-20141009|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=15 November 2015|archive-date=14 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151114180621/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/sheeran-busts-out-the-ballroom-moves-in-thinking-out-loud-video-20141009|url-status=live}}</ref> It became his second single to reach number one in the UK,<ref>{{cite news|last=Moss|first=Liv|date=2 November 2014|title=Ed Sheeran's Thinking Out Loud claims longest climb to Number 1 ever!|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/ed-sheeran-s-thinking-out-loud-claims-longest-climb-to-number-1-ever-__6890/|publisher=Official Charts Company|access-date=15 November 2015|archive-date=1 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151101201824/http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/ed-sheeran-s-thinking-out-loud-claims-longest-climb-to-number-1-ever-__6890/|url-status=live}}</ref> and it also spent eight weeks at number two on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] (with only \"[[Uptown Funk]]\" by [[Mark Ronson]] featuring [[Bruno Mars]] keeping it from top spot).<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6495240/mark-ronson-bruno-mars-10th-week-hot-100|title=\"Uptown Funk\" spends 10th week at No. 1, while Ed Sheeran spends eighth week at No. 2|last=Trust|first=Gary|date=11 March 2015|magazine=Billboard|access-date=15 November 2015|archive-date=6 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151106142614/http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6495240/mark-ronson-bruno-mars-10th-week-hot-100|url-status=live}}</ref> In 2014, combined [[streaming media|streams]] on Sheeran's catalogue in [[Spotify]] reached 860 million; Spotify named him the most-streamed artist and ''\u00d7'' the most-streamed album.<ref>{{cite news|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|date=3 December 2014|title=Ed Sheeran is Spotify's Most-Streamed Act for 2014|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/6334841/ed-sheeran-is-spotifys-most-streamed-act-for-2014|magazine=Billboard|access-date=15 November 2015|archive-date=4 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151104025649/http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/6334841/ed-sheeran-is-spotifys-most-streamed-act-for-2014|url-status=live}}</ref> In the same year, the album made Sheeran [[iTunes]]' best-selling artist in the UK, Ireland and New Zealand.<ref>{{cite news|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|date=8 December 2014|title=Ed Sheeran tops iTunes' UK bestseller list|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/dec/08/ed-sheeran-itunes-uk-bestsellers-list-sam-smith-frozen-coldplay-paolo-nutini|work=The Guardian|access-date=15 November 2015|archive-date=11 October 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151011225904/http://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/dec/08/ed-sheeran-itunes-uk-bestsellers-list-sam-smith-frozen-coldplay-paolo-nutini|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Rutledge|first=Daniel|date=9 December 2014|title=Pharrell, Ed Sheeran and Frozen top NZ iTunes 2014 charts|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/entertainment/pharrell-ed-sheehan-and-frozen-top-nz-itunes-2014-charts-2014120906|work=[[3 News]]|access-date=15 November 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n[[File:Ed Sheeran at Wembley 3 (19050650853).jpg|thumb|upright|Sheeran on stage at [[Wembley Stadium]], July 2015]]\n\n''\u00d7'' was nominated for Album of the Year at the [[57th Annual Grammy Awards|57th Grammy Awards]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-grammys-2015-nominees-winners-list-story.html|title=Grammys 2015: Complete list of winners and nominees|work=Los Angeles Times|date=8 February 2015|access-date=25 November 2015|archive-date=13 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151113092219/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-grammys-2015-nominees-winners-list-story.html|url-status=live}}</ref> Sheeran performed \"Thinking Out Loud\" alongside [[John Mayer]], [[Questlove]] and [[Herbie Hancock]] at the ceremony.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Flanagan|first=Andrew|title=Grammys 2015: Ed Sheeran Performs 'Thinking Out Loud' with Questlove, Herbie Hancock, John Mayer|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/grammys-2015/grammy-performances/6465571/grammys-2015-ed-sheeran-thinking-out-loud-herbie-hancock-john-mayer-questlove|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=7 August 2015|date=8 February 2015|archive-date=29 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150729075854/http://www.billboard.com/articles/grammys-2015/grammy-performances/6465571/grammys-2015-ed-sheeran-thinking-out-loud-herbie-hancock-john-mayer-questlove|url-status=live}}</ref> On 25 February, Sheeran won [[Brit Award for British Male Solo Artist|British Male Solo Artist]] and British Album of the Year for ''\u00d7'' at the [[2015 Brit Awards]].<ref name=\"Brits 2015\">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/feb/25/brit-awards-2015-the-full-list-of-winners|title=Brit awards 2015: the full list of winners|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|date=25 February 2015|work=The Guardian|access-date=21 November 2015|archive-date=21 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151121213835/http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/feb/25/brit-awards-2015-the-full-list-of-winners|url-status=live}}</ref> On 21 May he received the [[Ivor Novello Award]] for Songwriter of the Year.<ref name=\"Novello\">{{cite news|last=Denham|first=Jess|date=21 May 2015|title=Ivor Novello Awards 2015 winners list: Ed Sheeran, Clean Bandit and Hozier triumph|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/ivor-novello-awards-2015-winners-list-ed-sheeran-clean-bandit-and-hozier-triumph-10267714.html|work=The Independent|access-date=15 November 2015|archive-date=29 September 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929231816/http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/ivor-novello-awards-2015-winners-list-ed-sheeran-clean-bandit-and-hozier-triumph-10267714.html|url-status=live}}</ref> On 21 June, Sheeran co-hosted the [[2015 Much Music Video Awards]] in Toronto, where he performed the singles, \"Thinking Out Loud\" and \"[[Photograph (Ed Sheeran song)|Photograph]]\"; he also won two awards, Best International Artist and Most Buzzworthy International Artist or Group.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/entertainment/ed-sheeran-the-weeknd-rule-the-mmvas-drake-drops-in-as-a-surprise-1.2432898|title=Ed Sheeran, the Weeknd rule the MMVAs; Drake drops in as a surprise|last=Patch|first=Nick|date=21 June 2015|publisher=[[CTV News]]|access-date=15 November 2015|archive-date=17 November
